remixed_from.author: Despair
remixed_from.title: 1610 CNC end stop switches mounts and parts

description.text:
A collection of assorted upgrades for my Linksprite 1610 CNC.

  1. remix of Despair's Z plate to add a tab to tie the endstop wires to; wires connecting to moving parts like to break without strain relief.

  2. remix of Despair's X mounts to put the X endstops on the bottom. This keeps the top end of the CNC clean and I don't have to worry about any Z wires catching on anything. There's a loss of X travel, though, maybe 5-10 mm depending on how the X motor is mounted, but I'm okay with the tradeoff.

  3. A mount to add strain relief for the Z motor and endstop wires.

  4. A clip to hold the spindle wiring to the Z motor. Zip ties don't work so well if you want to be able to swap out the spindle.

I needed a gear for cutting some threads on my Colchester lathe. I don't think it will last if used permanently but it should do the trick for now and then use.The gears are solid if printed 0.2 and I have mounted it on the lathe and performed well.

Hope it helps some one else. Let me know if other sizes is needed.

I made a design after not finding it anywhere else. All I had was a 80mm fan. I can not say it is optimal, but it does work. The big gear on the extruder touch the fan, but it does not affect the gear. The most important thing is that it does not go below the hot end. Happy printing!
EDIT: Since it was my first i did it in something simple as tinkercad. It has a lot of bumps which are left from the multiple layers in tinkercad. I will try to make an improved version when I have the time. Feel free to do so if you don't want to wait.

title: Bluetooth Speaker - Quarter Wave Transmission Line
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After seeing a post on the CR10 Facebook group by Jason Bach, I decided to design my own 'quarter wave transmission line' Bluetooth Speaker - inspired by his work.

This thing is incredibly loud for it's size and the audio appears to be very nicely balanced considering this is made of plastic. It doesnt rattle or vibrate in any unwanted ways.

See video: https://youtu.be/yui068SL0e0

I had originally planned to sand and finish this, but the print came out so good, I just left it as it is.

This project requires 2x 3" speakers and a Bluetooth dual channel 50w Amp - Total cost about £30.
All of the parts mentioned in this project can be bought from ebay.

Full Bill of Materials below.

Firstly, I am not an audiophile. Nor do I know a huge amount about speakers and sound systems. I used some basic math to work out the required dimensions for the enclosure and the transmission line. The math revealed I needed a transmission line (or port/resonator) length of approx 777mm and its dimensions needed to be approx 90mmx33mm.

It's important to use the same speaker drivers as me (listed below), as the enclosure was designed specifically for their respective 'free air resonant frequency' and 'effective cone area'.

You can find out more about 'Quarter Wave Transmission Line' speakers and the math involved in a video link I posted in the comments section of this thing. It's similar to the wave technology Bose use. From watching the video, you could design your own enclosure for your own specific speakers.

Be advised - This is a large print! It takes approx 90 hours to print in total, and requires a build area of around 300x300x200 - so the CR10 is perfect for this project.

The side cover attaches with 6mm x 3mm magnets. 32 pairs of them. I glued them into position, triple checking the polarity of them each time. The side cover also has two little 'locator notches' to ensure it snaps on in the correct position easily. I am thinking about adding a self adhesive sheet of felt to the side cover, as it 'snaps' on quite violently with the pull of the magnets.

I added some self adhesive foam sheet inside the transmission line because something about absorbing unwanted resonant frequencies. I also added polyester pillow filling (polyfil) to the majority of the transmission line, which improved the bass sound so much. I might even experiment by adding more.

There are 4 recesses on the base of the speaker to allow you to fit 4x 1" self adhesive furniture felt feet so the speaker doesn't vibrate when placed on hard surfaces..

There are 2 holes on the back to allow fitment of a 20mm round on/off toggle switch and wireable 2.1 DC jack input.

There is an additional version with no holes on the back too, if you want to incorporate your own ideas.

You could easily run this off of some batteries for full portability. I might even add batteries to this myself.

Pro's & Cons of this project:

Pros:

  • Awesome looking little speaker and project.
  • Surprising loud for its small size. Like really loud in the mids and highs.
  • Relatively Cheap to make (~£30 + filament).

Cons:

  • There is a slight background hiss coming from the cheap bluetooth amp, noticeable at lower volume parts of audio tracks. Apparently this is normal for these to do this.
  • The bluetooth amp makes this horrible sounding chime when powered up.
  • Lacks bass in my opinion, but I do like listening to music with a bass heavy sound and with a sub normally.
    • The 20mm Switch I had in my 'bits box' appears to be a reversed switch, so it illuminates when up not pressed down (on).
  • Gluing the magnets into place was way more fiddly and messy than I had anticipated!!

Bill of Materials:

Approx 1.5kg Filament

  • 1 x Bluetooth 4.0 50W+50W Amplifier Board Audio Receiver TDA7492P
  • 2 x Faital Pro 3FE25 3" Speaker Driver 20W (40W max) 8 Ohm
  • Some 0.75mm copper cable
  • 12vdc AC adapter with a 2.1 plug (I had a spare 5A one lying around - I think 2A should work fine too, but not tested yet).
  • 64x 6mm round x 3mm deep neodymium magnets.
  • 8x M4x20mm screws
  • Super Glue or resin

Optional parts:

  • 20mm round toggle/rocker switch
  • 1 x male rewireable 2.1 plug
  • 1 x female rewireable 2.1 socket
  • 4 x 1" round felt feet
  • A4 Sheets of self adhesive foam
  • A4 Sheets of self adhesive felt
  • 12v LED strip lights to make the port illuminated
  • Polyester Pillow stuffing (polyfil).

I would love to see someone print this in a wood filament!!

Printer:

CR10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.28

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed in black PLA on a 2.3kg spool as the main enclosure uses well over 1kg of filament on its own - You could swap spools mid way through the print, but I wanted to 'fire and forget'.

Print speed: 60mm/s
Bed: PEI @ 60c
Hotend: Stock 0.4 nozzle at 210c for the entire print.

I used supports only for the large holes for the speaker drivers.

If I had to print this again, I would try it with a 0.8 nozzle and 0.4 layer height.

Amp and volume etc...

I run the amp at it lowest gain setting as the speakers are only 40w Max and the amp can allegedly run to 50W.

Using an iphone, the sound starts to distort at about 85-90% full volume on most tracks, but by this point it's so loud, it doesn't matter to me.

print_settings.Notes:: Support only touching the build plate.

description.text:
... this is the perfect digital to analog interface for mechanical engineers!

Consists of a "button pusher arm" and a bracket to hold down the servo.

I used two of these to automate my coffee maker: first servo pushes power button, a little Arduino nano checks if cup is present and waits for the coffee maker to heat up, second servo pushes button for one cup and finally first servo pushes power again to turn all off...

Thing includes both arm and clamp for small SG90 as well as stronger MG996R servos. Both types readily available for cheap on eBay.
In the front of the arm you can insert a M3 screw along with a nut (like the acrylic frames of many cheap 3D printers are held together). This allows for easy fine tuning without reprogramming the Arduino ask the time - as I said: mechanical solution approach;-)
To damp the impact of the screw to the button on my coffee maker I glued some small rubber bit to the head of the screw.

The servo horn fits into a matching groove and is held in place by ab drop of super glue. There is a hole in the arm to screw it together, with the horn glued in, to the servo itself.

... I'd appreciate feedback about the buttons you are pushing with this thing!

SG90 Onshape source:
https://cad.onshape.com/document-redirect.html?d=/documents/5c1d05cb2349c3440cd1c7e7/w/b97e94fe44b42bc04f3906ad

title: i3 mk3 extruder cover for i3 mk2

description.text:
When putting together the mk3, I preferred the fan shroud of the mk3. So I decided to modify the i3 mk2 extruder cover to allow it to use the new fan shroud. This is a basically a merging of the Prusa i3 mk2 and mk3 extruder cover.

The i3 mk3 fan shroud is taken directly from prusa's site, I've just included it for convenience.

comments.text:
Hi, i've just printed the part to fit it on mk2.. But i cannot assemble it!
The part is too short and the fan shroud interfere with the pinda probe!
comments.author: Malo87

comments.text: I'm not really sure what to say, I didn't have any trouble putting it on mine, and it doesn't seem to be interfering with the pinda probe when printing
comments.author: Malo87

comments.text: Maybe I've not understood correctly. Isn't this a rework of the Mk2 extruder to fit the Mk3 fan shroud? I've got the mk2 extruder body. Have you designed it on the mk2s part? When trying to assemble it, the fan shroud was at the heater block level instead that the nozzle level. It looks like the cover is too short by 1 cm. I'll try to make a picture later when I've finish the current prints.
comments.author: Wes1180

comments.text: It's looks like it's at the same height as it is on the mk3, I believe the fan shroud is angled in such a way that it blows over the nozzle instead of the heater block.
comments.author: Malo87

comments.text: Ok, I've got to the bottom of the issue. The part is definitely ok if you've got the original mk2 extruder body. If yo've replaced the extruder body with the newer mk2s version (like I did, and forgot about), the mk3 fan shroud hits the pinda probe holder!

description.text:
EDIT
I lost 20mm print space on my right hand side due to this upgrade but I;m getting some smaller flanged bearings im going to re model this part for so I will upload the updated version asoon as I get the bearings and make the model. its still going to have the 8mm plugs to hold the bearings im going to make the tensioner smaller and get rid of the discs at the sides of the bearings

EDIT
I've added a new part it uses the 608 bearing still but this is smaller and give you the 20mm print area back

needed 1 608z bearing

I've made 2 caps that go inbetween the bearing and idler bracket to accommodate the 8mm hole (instead of using an 8mm bolt) then just thread a normal bolt through to close them together 1 side of the caps has a recess to allow the bolt head to sit in so it doesn't collide with the little screw in the frame of the printer the 2 plates that go either side of the bearing is from someone elses model on here I will credit them when I find there files again. this works perfect on my ctc prusa i3 if you encounter any problems please let me know and also if you make this file please post pics

title: Imperial Assault Deployment Card Holder MKII

description.text:
This is an improvement on my previous design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2584292). Turn out even with the holders, I end up flicking damage tokens all over the table. I really hate those damage tokens.

With three 0-9 wheels you can mark any character deployment in the game (at least in the expansions I have. Either 0-9 for smaller guys, or use two wheels for bigger characters like Vader.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Holder - I used supports on build plate only, in hindsight it might have worked better without that option. there's a bit of cleanup to clear out support and fit cards nicely. You could if you wanted change out to a different colour filament at 3.4mm (layer 23 at 0.2mm/layer) to make the indicator/stoppers stand out. That was my plan with my run of 6 but I had to leave unexpectedly and wasn't home to change it out.

Counter wheels - Print three. The wheel is face down in the STL. I found that printing that way, while using a slightly lower bed/nozzle temp allowed the rather small numbers the resolve correctly. You'll want to change colour before it starts the solid layers so the contrasting colour shows through the hollow numbers. In my case at 0.2mm per layer changing at layer 5 (1mm) did the trick. Your results/settings may vary depending on your filament/printer I think. I'm using pretty cheap eSun stuff right now.

Be careful fitting the wheels to the holders. I had one shaft break in an early test and shaved .25mm of the diameter and its been fine, but still good to be careful.

First time you put a card in be careful in case there are leavings from the supports.

description.text:
These are the pulley cases that we have been using on all of our Rev slides. We have used them for prototypes in the Res-Q season and the Velocity Vortex season and we use them on our robot this year (Relic Recovery). These cases are simple to assemble, requiring for each pulley:

  • One of each 3d printed part
  • 2 M3 screws that are long enough
  • 2 small M3 washers - They have to be small enough that they only touch the inner ring on the bearing

To assemble these, you screw them together with the pulley in the inside, with one washer surrounding each pulley.

This is a caddy for an old PC ATX power supply. I needed a beefy 12V power supply and found an old ATX unit. The power supply fits in the hole exacty, and then pushes down to be retained by a lip, the wires from the power supply can be left intact and tucked above the power supply.

The power supply I had was an old format, this holder will need modification for a newer style power supply, as the air flow in mine is front to back, rather than the new ones which go top to side.

It took a long time to print, and the layer shift you see in mine was due to it hitting something during printing, it's not part of the model. I messed up a little with the positioning of the cut outs for the power leads (rear lip), but it still fits OK.

Had to rotate the model 45 degrees to get it to fit on a 20x20cm build platform (just fits).

print_settings.Notes:: See main text.

title: Advanced Drill Dust Collector for Vacuum Cleaners

description.text:
[Updates: see below]

This is a quite extensively optimized dust collector for standard vacuum cleaners suitable for small 3D printers. It adheres to the wall and leaves your hands free for drilling holes. There are a couple of related devices on Thingiverse but for me they did not really work well. Either the connection to the vacuum hose was too close to the wall, or they did not adhere firmly on rough walls, or they were simply too large for my printer. So I designed one from scratch. It fits vacuum tubes with 35 mm outer diameter which are quite common in Europe, particularly for wet/dry utility vacuum cleaners. Please let me know if you need different dimensions. If time allows I will try to provide a suitable version.

This dust collector has a few rather unique characteristics:

  1. It has extremely good adhesion even on rough and uneven walls. This is achieved by following design features:

    • A thin "skirt" surrounding the device which reduces leakage. It is a little bit flexible, thus adapting to shallow bumps and dents. It may be a bit fragile, though, so please comment on this.
    • A large effective adhesion area, i.e., almost the entire footprint area contributes to the vacuum region.
    • A separated vacuum pocket at the back which prevents the device from being easily detached by normal and tilt forces, e.g. when the vacuum hose is under mechanical tension. This pocket is connected to the main vacuum chamber via small bypass channels such that dust does not accumulate there.
  2. It is easy to print. No support structures are needed. PLA is a good choice. Just print it in "upright" orientation (see stl file).
  3. It is suitable even for very small 3D printers. The size in any direction does not exceed 100 mm.
  4. It keeps a distance between vacuum hose and wall, hence it is suited for vacuum cleaners with a larger fitting piece behind the connector tube ("thickening", see first photo). Yet the hose is kept almost parallel to the wall which avoids large tilting torques.
  5. Airflow cross section is optimized, there are no major constrictions where the air must be "squeezed through".
  6. It is lightweight and only needs ~ 34 g of material.
  7. Well, I tried to give it an attractive design, although this is certainly a matter of taste. It somehow reminds me of a hovercraft vehicle :-) Actually, if you think about it, there are indeed some very related design criteria!

Please comment and share your experiences!

UPDATE 2018/03/10: Added file "AdvDustCollector_35mm_tightFit.stl". If the outer diameter of the vacuum connection tube is exactly 35mm (not 35.5mm as in my case) this will fit better.

Some hints:
The only critical part during printing is the topmost region of the thin skirt which needs some time for cooling. Using a minimum of ~ 10 - 15 s layer time (in slicer settings) worked fine and hardly affects the total duration. 20% filling is recommended. I used a 0.4 mm nozzle and 0.2 mm layer thickness.
If you need a slightly different diameter of the vacuum connection (by 1 - 3 mm or so) you can simply scale the thing along the xy-directions (or in all directions if space allows).

customized with 3D Slash!

This is a slight model change of Fat Cat thing 901128 that I used for printing. It solved slicing issues I had with Simplify and prints well without support.

The changes from the original thing 901128

  1. Removed the base plate. I like the cat to be 'free'.
  2. Run though netfabb stl fixer. This eliminate severe stl issues that confuses Simplify3D slicer
  3. Flatten the bases of the feet, belly and head for easier printing.
  4. Scaled up for a size I like (you can still scale up or down to your preferred size while slicing it)
  5. Rotated 90 degrees along the Z access to fit the orientation of my FFCP build plate.

For the record, this is the openscad script I used to make the modifications

k=2.27;

intersection() {
  scale([k, k, k]) 
  rotate([0, 0, -90])
  translate([0, 0, -0.9]) 
    import("FatCat2_fixed.stl", convexity=3);

  cylinder(d=130, h=70);
}

This is an adapter to allow my old vacuum cleaner hose to fit onto a Henry.

The aim for this project was to be able to use my existing hose without modifying it. I achieved this by creating a flange to push onto the hose and a screw cap to seal onto to vacuum.

The diameter of the screw cap is 62mm, making it an M62x4 thread, with a 35mm hole through the center to allow free rotation.

The flange has a 33.5mm port for the hose (my hose is 33mm in diameter). This allows the hose to push fit in my case, but other prints may need a spot of glue.

To assemble, first put the cap on the hose, then push the flange on - as shown in the photos.

I've got a breakdown of my design process on my blog here:

https://plabs107524285.wordpress.com/2018/02/25/designing-a-hose-adapter-for-henry/

print_settings.Notes:: TOTAL PRINT TIME: 102hrs

description.text:
We held a friendly office competition that we began to refer to as "Sharkvivor". After looking around for a bit and stumbling upon the Beefy Shark (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:229538) model, I knew what I had to do; scale it up, and make the best damn trophy ever 3d printed by mankind!

I had originally planned to design it to be the exact maximum size that could be printed as 1 solid piece in my Ultimaker 3 Extended. However, during the design process I got a little carried away and had to split it into 3 main pieces to be able to print it.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3 Extended

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:
Beefy Shark Topper
  • Print Settings: 0.2 layer height @ 20% infill
  • Supports: Yes, PVA support material
  • Print Time: 58hrs
Trophy Cup
  • Print Settings: 0.2 layer height @ 20% infill
  • Supports: No
  • Print Time: 22hrs
Trophy Base
  • Print Settings: 0.1 layer height w/ adaptive layer heights on @ 20% infill
  • Supports: No
  • Print Time: 21hrs
Name Plate
  • Print Settings: 0.2 layer height @ 20% infill
  • Supports: No
  • Print Time: 1hr
TOTAL PRINT TIME: 102hrs

Support Removal

I removed a large amount of the PVA support material by hand being careful not to get too close to the printed surface. After that, Beefy Shark went for a swim in my kitchen sink for ~2 days with me draining the water and replacing with fresh warm water every few hours.

Beefy Shark likes to float which makes removing the PVA that much more difficult. With some zip ties and a hitch ball, I was able to keep him under water.

Drying

The model took on a little bit of water during the PVA removal process so it was necessary to let it dry out for ~1 day, rotating it on a stack of paper towels every so often to allow the water to drain out of the crevices.

Assembly

Assembly is pretty straightforward. I super glued everything together with Gorilla Glue Super Glue Gel.

Knowing I was going to paint the top, I did mask off the base and cut out the hole beforehand to make things easier.

Paint

I used some gold spray paint to give the trophy that necessary gold look. I had printed it using gold PLA but wasn't impressed with the gold color.

title: Prusa i3 Mk3 Roller Spool Holder

description.text:
This is Remix of the excellent universal spool roller unit & stand by DWONH. See the original thing for assembly diagram.
It uses 608zz bearings, no bolts and nuts are required to assemble.
Rollers are 120mm long which should be sufficient for most 1kg filament spools.

I was unhappy with the supplied spool holder on the new Original Prusa i3 Mk3 printer. Although a large improvement on the Mk2 version I still found it flimsy and would "bounce" the roll of filament producing movement in the Z axis frame.

I took DWONH's superb universal spool roller unit and redesigned it to incorporate the wide Prusa i3 Mk3 frame mounts as used on their new spool holder. This is a strong well fitting mount that snaps on the the frame with a little effort and holds strongly.

I also designed a matching filament guide, with a removable guide hoop which is split for those of us who always forget to insert our filament through the hoop before loading it!

description.text:
My printer stands on a wheeled tool cabinet, which is steel. I was using sticky pads to fix things to the sides, but this wasn't very successful. So, I am creating magnetic mounts which will fix the cabling etc to the cabinet.

This is the first one, which will mount a UK mains block (perhaps others too) to the side. It has cutouts in the base to accommodate two 30x10x5 mm magnets and four strips of 20mm adhesive foam (to add friction to stop it slipping)

It then has two lugs on the front to locate into the keyhole slots on the mains block and a flat base on which the block can rest.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20% - (100% for lugs)

Notes:

I sliced this in Simplify3d. Due to the size of the lugs on the pins, you must print these and the layer below at 100% infill. I split into two processes, doing the base at 20% and the top at 100%.

I printed in ABS to get the extra strength. I expect that PLA may be too brittle.

Print with the base down and with support for the cut-outs.

I have included the Simplify3D factory file for those who have it.

Assembly

Simply remove the support material and cut the foam into strips and stick into the cut-outs. I stuck the magnets in with epoxy glue.

You can make it with a laser cuter or with a CNC. Pay attention to any inside corner. Due of the size of the bit of your CNC you will have to make "dogbones" chamfer (or corner) to make it fit.
File named _dogbones have the inside corner done. Cause it could be painful to do it by hand and some software let you do that easy.

My CNC is a 3020 so you can build the tree in this size (300mm x 200mm). I recommend to make it with a Laser cut. It's more efficient.

Wood thickness : 5mm

You don't need to glue it but you can. This one was never glued.

I made it for my girlfriend. To help her to forget that I bought a CNC machine. Now it's my wife, so it did work pretty well !

description.text:
This is a prototype tank/rover track which is 559mm long with 35 tooths and holes. The teeth are 8mm tall and the track thickness is 0,8mm, the track is 30mm wide and the holes are 8mm by 8mm.

The track feels great, it's very flexible and has huge potential. Drivegears and more rover parts might be uploaded later but I wanted to share the track just in case someone else wanted to use it for their rover.

Printed in TPC with an hardness of 45D

My wife and I use clothespins for all sorts of stuff, but mostly for keeping food bags closed. They're dirt cheap and more durable than the plastic ones they sell for a few bucks each (!).

To save space, I printed a few of these and used the medium sized 3M Command Strips to attach them to the inside of our cupboard.

I would strongly recommend mounting them vertically for ergonomic reasons.

description.text: Hey, everyone! This is my first upload to Thingiverse, and actually my first 3D design. This is my custom laser gun, designed to work with the laser module and button from my Colemeter Mini Laser Engraver (or any clone). This particular gun has a 1000mW laser, and is as simple as the laser module, button, and some AA batteries. That's it! At the moment it has only 4 AA batteries in it (which is still powerful enough to burn paper or plastic), but you could add up to 5 or 6 AA batteries in series to make it even more powerful. The design will need to be slightly modified depending on the laser and button you choose to use, but that's as simple as just increasing or decreasing the diameters of the two holes. So far it works great, but make sure you wear protective glasses (to shield your eyes from the light), and don't point it at anyone obviously!

Printer:

Anycubic i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The hole for the laser module was a little too small in this design, but that was easily fixed with some sandpaper. There's plenty of room for batteries (really any kind), but I'm using AA batteries.
To design this I used Autodesk Inventor 2016 (Student Version). It only took about an hour, and it was a great design to start learning CAD design in my opinion.

description.text:
I began looking for a filament storage/dispenser box and found many. Most had the PVC supports which, although functional, are a pain when you need to change out an empty spool. After considering sever roller designs, i decided to try ant0ni0's Filament Storage - Quick Change design. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:859426

Unfortunately, the his supports would not fit in the AWSOME storage container that I found at Walmart: "Hefty PROTECT Heavy Duty Storage, 20 Qt. Lid with Protective Seal / Clear"

I started to tweak his mesh and quickly became frustrated (with my own mesh editing ability) and realized it would be faster, for me, to model the thing from scratch. I added enough clearance over the support for a 8x30x10 u-groove roller if I decide to splurge in the future. (although I believe the friction of the printed roller will help me prevent a mess when a spool freewheels after an abrupt tug...)

Also Needed:
(2) 8 mm (5/16") rods x 340mm (13.375")

Update:
I enlarged the ID of the roller for clearance on an 8 mm rod.

description.text:
***NOW INCLUDES 2 STYLES OF ENCLOSURES**

Style 1 (Extreme Strength) Cost $25
Required Items: COMPLETE PVC Foamboard Enclosure (Top Shelf) v4.1
8 printed PVC Enclosure End Cap v4.1
4 printed PVC Enclosure Top Hole Guide Caps (not required)
3*10 feet of 3/4" PVC (only 20 feet needed for simple enclosure with no upright support)
6 sheets of dollar tree foam board (DTFB)
Hot glue gun
Packing tape
Scotch tape

Style 2 (Effective and Durable) Cost $6
Required Items: BARE BONES Foamboard Enclosure v1
8 printed BARE BONES Foamboard Enclosure End Cap v1
4 printed PVC Enclosure Top Hole Guide Caps (not required)
6 sheets of dollar tree foam board (DTFB)
tooth picks (not required)
Hot glue gun
Packing tape
Scotch tape

Lets be honest here, we are DIY people and should have glue guns and tape everywhere we turn so the cost is less than $25

(purchase 10 sheets of DTFB if you need a taller design - simply tape the long edges together on both sides)

This was a simple idea I had to make an enclusre that was adaptable to any size I wanted and be able to source all the parts I needed locally here in my small rural town in Southern Illinois. All you need is to print 8 of these corner braces, purchace 6 sheets of "dollar tree foam board" and 3-10ft 3/4" pvc pipes.. Cost is about 25 bucks total and this is easily adapted to use a smaller PVC pipe if you choose.

I do not use foam board on the top and opted for a 1/4 sheet of plywood cut to fit so I had addtional storage on top for FILAMENT. (must use the Veftical PVC supports) This works fantastic and you can create doors anywhere you want with a razor and packing tape.. I designed screw holes into the brackets to secure the wooden top on..

Making it modular was key for me because I have several machines and not all have the SD card, power switch, filament feed, and printer controls loacted in the same place.

Simply locate where you want an access door, cut a slit where the door will hinge, then immediately tape the length of that cut. Now cut out the shape of the door and swing it open fully. While holding it open place another piece of tape along the inside of the hinge. (scotch tape or "hot glue smere" can be used on the cut edges for longevity)

This is a no muss no fuss design and replacing panels only takes a single piece of foam board that costs $1...

(no print supports are needed and this design does not require glue or fastners)

Everything fits together really snug but additional steps can be taken to both better insulate and firm up the design.

Run a beed of hot glue along the PVC pipe where it touches the FOAM BOARD or simply use packing tape. I prefer to use HOT GLUE on the inside and on the corners on the outside I used ALUMINUM DUCT TAPE.. Neither of these steps are need for functional ABS printing on any machine I own. Even the very sensitive I3 Mega works well without it!

***I have included a picture of how I assembled it for simple use as a removable enclosure just for retaining heat (NO VERTICAL PVC UPRIGHTS)****

(Latest Update 03-08-2018)
When using upright supports for a top shelf I was concerned that too much weight on the shelf may cause shifting so I added holes to tap through to the PVC to secure it with a screw. AS a result I had to modify the top hole (cosmetic) guide accordingly..

MEMBER REQUEST UPDATE - (see zip file BARE BONE)
I modified the entire file to completely exclude pvc from the build and the corner caps are now more of a modular corner protector and simply using a dab of hot glue to secure the foam board is all that is required for longevity.. I left the holes in the design if anyone was interested in pushing a few toothpicks through them with hot glue for additional support.

Fusion 360 files have been moved to the ZIP files

description.text:
I needed to solder some copper pipe to install water filters. A few of the pieces were small and difficult to hold while cleaning the pipe. So I made this expanding pipe holder for 3/4" pipe. It works great, it turned the most difficult pieces to clean into the easiest. I used a 5/16" bolt because the bolt, washers, and nut, would all fit inside the pipe. The flexible parts expand slightly to grip the pipe as you tighten the nut. Then you put the end of the bolt in a drill and use sandpaper to clean the pipe as it spins.

The inner pieces are generic flexible TPU filament, at first I tried to print the flexible piece as one piece, it didn't adhere to the bed, so I made it a two piece unit and it prints easily. The two outside cones are PLA. All parts are printed slow with 100% infill. You need to print two flexible TPU parts and two PLA parts.

description.text:
This is an adaptation to "Hanphry's" "CR-10_FanMod-_easy_to_install" fan duct mod.
I have put the exit of the duct centered on the print nozzle.
Have added extra support to the screw tabs, this makes the unit a little wider than the fan but not as wide as the print head cover. I have also added a 1° angle to the mounting surface in way of the screws, this will help the duct nozzle side from hanging low and hitting the print.
Modified the vertical duct wall's to aid airflow and removed the exit supports, this I thought was restricting the airflow. Since the top edge was curved around the nozzle with no support I suggest putting temporary support in this area.

I saw several videos and tutorials on bushing extractors with home depot supplies, so I tried something different: print it in a 3D printer yourself.
You only need to use one of the bridge posts to screw down on, and the bushing will slowly separate from the body of the guitar.
I didn't have any problems with the bushings on my guitar:
-The outer diameter of the protruding top of the bushing is about 14,5mm and the inner diameter of the extractor is 16mm. On any bushing that's 14,5mm or less will work.
-The diameter of the threaded part of the post is 8mm, and the upper hole is 8,5 mm so any thread of 8mm or less will work.
-The head of the post should be as big as it can be in order not to crack or break the extractor. The one I used is about 14mm.

(I'm very happy with my new bridge)

The inductive charger built into the center armrest of the second-generation Volt is a nice touch, but until there's a Bluetooth version of CarPlay, it renders the phone not very useful. So I remixed TheAdmrl's excellent iPhone holder to press fit a charging pad. The required scaling up also makes it possible to just press fit the holder into the opening in the center console. I beveled the left and right ends for a tighter fit.

I learned a lot about TinkerCad doing this, but not enough to be able fill in the channels for the lifters in the original design, so this should be printed with supports everywhere.

FYI, my iPhone 6 is in a Tech21 case. The charging pad is a Upow S3, which doesn't seem to be available through Amazon anymore. Any pad 3.0 inches in diameter should work, though. Or you could forego the charging pad entirely...

Filing to Fit

Radan CAD/CAM 3D

author: Earthican

description.text:
remix of a previous model.

use this to measure the kerf of your laser cutter for various materials. set the laser to use the same settings you want to use for cutting your chosen material, then grab all the tiny rectangles and put them back into the slot. finally place the cover with two holes over the pieces to prevent them from scattering everywhere when you try to measure the size. secure the parts with m3 bolts and washers.

write the speed and power settings used on the back, along with your calculated kerf.
I have a drawer full of different materials that i can go back and reference.

to calculate kerf:
1) measure the tab (should be around 110mm) record as 'A'
2) in the two slots provided measure the width of the combined rectangles, record as 'B'
3) kerf = (A-B)/10

now you can plug that into your cam processor to adjust for the laser kerf.

Hallo zusammen,
eigentlich wollte ich mir einen Vorpal Hexabot machen. Nachdem ich mir das Gehäuse ausgedruckt hatte, musste ich allerdings bemerken, dass die 9G Servos welche ich hatte, da nicht wirklich passen. Und da ich nicht der Profi bin, stehe ich schnell einmal auf verlorenem Posten, wenn ich keine SolidWorks Datei als Basis habe. Denn auch wenn ich mir die Datei in SW importiere, bleiben immer in paar importierte Elemente übrig, welche ich nicht umwandeln kann.
Was also tun…..? Entweder in SW das Original neu zeichnen und eine Kopie vom Original machen, oder eben gleich selbst etwas Neues zeichnen…. Wobei ich dann aber wieder beim Programmieren vor einem für mich (noch) unlösbaren Problem stehen würde…
Also habe ich mich dazu entschieden mich einerseits selbst an etwas heran zu wagen, mich dabei aber an der Positionierung der Servos und der Abstände am Original zu orientieren. Was nun zu einer etwas komisch anmutenden Grundplatte geführt hat. Jedoch sollte nichts daran hindern auf diese ein Oberteil zu setzen, welches gefällt.

Die Carbon sytle Seitenteil der "Schwenker" dienen bei dem Design zur Zeit aber nur um die Abmessungen für die endgültigen Teile zu eruieren. Denn mein Design hier ist ja nur als Basis zum selbst weitermachen angedacht. Oder dass eben vielleicht mein Servogehäuse mit Kugellager für den Einen oder Anderen auch für eine andere Konstruktion von Nutzen sein könnte.

Wenn ich das Teil so wie erhofft fertig stellen und zum Laufen bringen kann, wird der Rest natürlich folgen. Und bis dahin vorerst einmal die Servohalterung wie vorgestellt. Weitere verschiedene "Schwenkerteile" habe ich inzwischen dazugefügt, damit man die Wahl zwischen seitlicher Befestigung oder Befestigung von Oben hat. Die Taschen sind dabei für Gewindeeinsätze M2.5mmm gedacht.

Nun sind auch die Schwenker für das Futaba S3003 Servo gezeichnet, ausgedruckt und geprüft.. Auch ein weiteres Gehäuse mit Kugellager für den S3003 Servo ist jetzt fertig geworden und die Dateien dazu habe ich hier hinzugefügt.

Teile und Infos zum Druck:

Kugellager 6x13x3.5
Gewindeeinsätze M2.5
Servos 9G
Gedruckt auf C-Bot CK1 Düse 0.4
Material PLA Volcano
Schicht 0.2/0.1
Druckgeschwindigkeit 25/40mm sek.
Software Simplify 3D (Bei sensiblen Stellen habe ich Druckgeschwindigkeit und Layer Höhe ab der entsprechenden Stelle reduziert.)

P.s.
Der Grundrahmen vom letzten Bild und er Animation sind die Basis für einen etwas grösseren Hexapod, die Teile für die grösseren Servos werden folgen.
Das Design ist aber auch hier so ausgelegt, das alle gedruckten Teile auf einem Drucker mit 250er Druckbett ausgedruckt werden können. Nur die Bodenplatte ist gefräst, oder würde eine grössere Druckfläche erfordern.

Sorry but my brain is somehow not able to write that stuff in English.

Printer:

C-Bot CK1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Da mir Konstruktionen bei welchen Original Servohörner verbaut werden nicht so gefallen, habe ich hier auch gleich ein paar eigene gezeichnet, welche verschiedene Aufnahmemöglichkeiten bieten. Bei den hier veröffentlichten Servohörnern würde ich zudem empfehlen diese zuerst einmal bei einem Servo mit Metallverzahnung einzupressen.
Weil es aber bei den Hörnern genauso wie auch bei den Servogehäusen wieder massig Unterschiede bei den Abmessungen gibt, habe ich hier auch gleich die SW files hochgeladen, damit euch eventuell notwendige Anpassungen leicht möglich werden. Und für jene welche nicht die Möglichkeit für Anpassungen haben, habe ich gleich ein kleines Sortiment der Schwenker in STL Format hier eingestellt.
Bei dem kleinen Teil dürften die Schwenker so wie gezeichnet kaum eine Option sein, weshalb ich noch andere gezeichnet habe, welche auch bei der kleinen Grundplatte diverse Optionen zur Aufnahme der Arme bieten dürften.
Und wie bereits erwähnt, werde ich das Design so gestalten, dass alle Teile ausser eben der Bodenplatte mit einem 250x250 Druckbett gedruckt werden können.
Die Bodenplatte kann dann im Notfall bei MachWas (www.machwas-makerspace.ch) bestellt werden, der Preis richtet sich nach dem Material.
Und wer unser Projekt gerne unterstützen möchte, findet alle Informationen bei uns auf der Seite.

author: Captain_sq

description.text:
Had to fix the spacers on the back of a smeg fridge (between the wall and the fridge, the same screws that keep the top of the fridge in place), this print should be printed laying down horizontally (not up like it's aligned originally) to create a strong part.

Not sure if this will be of help to someone, but it should also work as a general spacer for fridges that use those spacers. The spacers printed actually worked a lot better than the original spacers.

It's hard to break. The 3.5mm depth for the screws should let you screw the part in without the fear of breaking the part, just be sure not to over-tighten the screw and ruin the threads, be especially aware of this when tightening on plastic threads.

Standard M4 screws should fit nicely, the hole is Ø5mm diameter, M5 will drill into the plastic but shouldn't break the part.

description.text: Handful of bases for Tau. 25mm infantry bases plus 3 larger battlesuit bases.

This is my first attempt at designing and printing from scratch. I needed a more organized system to store my rolls of filament so I developed a simple wall rack made of 1x2 sections and 3/4 inch dowels. There is a left and right lower section and a top piece to mount to the wall. I glued the top and bottom with silicone RTV but you can also use crazy glue or similar adhesive. You can use 3/4 inch wood dowels or as I did 3/4 inch aluminum decking rails. I also cut a corner wedge and installed it to add more support. That is purely optional.
This was done on an Anet A8 with no special settings. I was able to lay the print on its side but you can also print upright if desired.

author: Xyruss

description.text:
This is a 28mm model of the Red Army's 37mm AA gun, Model 1939.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/37_mm_automatic_air_defense_gun_M1939_(61-K)
I started with Kpi's model of the Bofors, and adapted his file to represent the Soviet gun. I separated the model, and re-crafted the gun mount to represent the Russian gun. Likewise for the recoil system.
First thing to do after printing the parts, please glue the Gun mount to the gun mount bottom (both are approx 39mm). This gun mount will then sit on the actual gun base.
I tend to sacrifice accurate scale on smaller parts in favour of making the model more robust, but I did include the various elevation wheels and sights represented on the actual gun. I made the gun barrel movable; although do take care mounting it in the pivot points. I made a trough in the gun mount to help ease it in.
The wheels/tires (thanks to kpi's excellent design) have a "flat spot; please make sure that goes towards the ground.
If you have any questions or suggestions, please drop me a message.
Thanks

title: Customizable Flower Pot - classic style
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Spring is coming and there are lots of plants to get started. Here's a customizable flower pot to help. I'm not sure how well PLA really works as flower pot material (it should be fine), but you don't have to actually put real plants in them. Plastic plants - that would seem to be rather appropriate. Easter eggs might work, too. Jelly beans would also be a good choice for the smaller ones.

So, why spend time and money printing out something you can easily buy for less than a dollar? That's the wrong question for those of us on Thingiverse who print tons of often useless stuff.

A better question is why would I spend many hours building a flower pot algorithm in OpenSCAD. Since you asked, I was having fun re-discovering geometry and trigonometry and algebra - stuff I hadn't used since high school and stuff that most people, at that time in their lives, forget as soon as they can.

On with the flower pot: At the time of this writing, Thingiverse's Customizer is a little broken in that it won't display a preview of your model as you change the parameters. While it will still generate a perfect STL file, the lack of preview makes it difficult to judge what settings you need to change in order to get the results you want. The PTB have been notified of the bug, but don't seem to be able to fix it.

In hopes of helping a little, I've uploaded a picture pointing out the parameters you can change and what part of the flower pot they affect.

Some notes on using the Customizer.

While the program tries to limit values to ranges that work well, it's still possible to produce un-printable results if you color outside the lines, so to speak. For example: the design includes a fillet under the rim of the pot. This is intended to make the pot printable without any supports. It can look really strange and un-pot-like at extreme pot side angles and large rim sizes.

The side and base thickness can be left to the program (set each to '0'). The program will set them based, roughly, on the base diameter chosen. However, you can set each dimension manually, if you wish.

If you use all the defaults, you get the pot pictured in the dimensions diagram.

As always, you can download the OpenSCAD code and get around the sanity limits. I've tried to comment the heck out of it, but it's the result of several different design attempts and a lot of iterations to get the calculations correct. It's not complicated, really. Just a bit messy.

I understand there are other, possibly easier, ways to create a pot. Excellent idea. Make one of your own and post the link here. I'll probably print it out.

Here's a brief overview of each parameter you can customize (all dimensions in mm or deg):

Base Diameter: the diameter of the outer edge of the pot's base. The program limits this to a range: 10-350. When making a saucer, add from 10-20mm to the pot's diameter to get an appropriately-sized saucer.

Height of Pot: the height of the pot from the base to the top of the rim. The program limits this to a range: 8-350. Hint: a pot's saucer is just a shorter, wider pot.

Pot SIde Angle: As the included picture shows, this is the number of degrees from vertical. Zero degrees gives a vertical side. The Customizer limits this to a range: 0-30deg in 1-degree increments.

Rim Side Angle: Also, the number of degrees from vertical. The Customizer limits this to a range: 0-30deg. The program also limits this - the rim angle can't be greater than the Pot Side Angle. It can be less, and actually looks a bit better if it is.

Height of Rim: The rim is the band around the top-edge of the pot. The Customizer limits this to a range: 0-200mm. The program limits the rim height to a bit less than the height of the pot. If you set this to zero, you get a round rim.

Rim Thickness: How thick should the rim be? The program limits this to a range: 0-10mm. Set this to zero to eliminate the rim.

Drain Hole: If you use this to pot plants, or simply for appearance, you can put a drain hole in the bottom of the pot by selecting "Yes." The diameter of the hole is determined by the program and is based on the pot base's diameter. If you choose a drain hole, the program ignores the "risers" setting.

Pot Risers: In real life, the pot usually has some feet or something on the bottom to allow the drain to work. To make the pot printable without supports, I had to move the "risers" to the top of the "saucer." If you want risers, you can't also have a drain hole. The program determines the dimensions of the risers based on the pot base's diameter.

Sidewall Thickness: The thickness of the pot's walls. If you set this to zero, the program will calculate a value based on the pot base's diameter. You may also set this manually. The program limits this to a range: 1-6mm.

Base Thickness: The thickness of the pot's base. If you set this to zero, the program will calculate a value based on the pot base's diameter and it will be a little thicker than the sidewalls. You may also set this manually. The program limits this to a range: 1-7mm.

Final note: the models included with this "thing" are examples and are not necessarily the ones in the photos.

I heated up the shank and pressed in both sides to form a tight fit then put the screw that holds the key in place back. The other thing I did is sculpt the key holes so that there is a slight indentation to make it easier to press the buttons. I may try to remix again and add that as a feature but for now this was a one time print project for me. I also used Bondic to fill the light hole then sanded it all smooth. A bit rough but overall satisfied with the results.

Post print processing

I used a sander and dremel to smooth out the rough spots and sculpt the key holes a bit so there is a slight indentation where the buttons are. I also had to heat the key shank and fit it into the parts. It made a nice tight fit that won't wiggle loose.

TinkerCad

Added a new hole from the original using TinkerCad. Also rotated it flat to make printing easier.

We have a 40 foot long washing line between wall mounted pulley and tree meaning it is approx 12 feet off the ground when pulled tight. This winch is mounted to wall so that washing line can be lowered and tightened.

Please be nice, I am new to all this.
Winch is probably way over engineered, but a 40 foot line can hold a great deal of weight, so I was being cautious.
Not for the faint hearted, this winch is heavy chunks of plastic, it will take most of a 1KG reel to print. Pictures show winch printed on RepRap Metric Mendel Prusa with LM8UU bearings, printed in translucent red 3mm PLA. Top shown in photos is a previous version (15mm thick instead of final 10mm). Winch.scad is main file, it pulls M45 threads from ISOThread.scad, vertical bearings from vert_bear.scad and horizontal bearings from horiz_bear.scad.
Needs approx 116 off 6mm steel ball bearings. Near top of Winch.scad are 4 lines:
//winch();
//winch_base();
//winch_top();
//winch_reel();
uncommenting top line allows viewing of all parts as assembled.
uncommenting any of next three lines allows rendering three components for rendering to STL. Vertical and horizontal bearings include lips so that bearings may be clipped in and will then be held in place. Allways leave space for one bearing when loading. Photo shows ball bearings loaded. Winch base has built in support material for vertical bearings, 'generate support' in Slic3r should be off to print this.
Winch reel will not print unless 'generate support' is ON. We have actually had a washing line winch in place in our garden for about 10 years, one of the photos shows one of the 'prototypes'.
Currently had the new winch in place and working for 2 weeks, I don't know how well it will wear or anything else, but it works well so far. Winch now been installed and fully working for almost 2 years, red PLA has faded slightly, but wooden ball handle could not cope with weather, split in half, so new file Winch2.scad and knob.stl are a PLA replacement, fitted and working very well.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Among the first designs for my cnc I did some simplified 3 layered animals. Later two dinosaurs, a Stegosraurus and the Triceratops joined in. I always thought the Tyrannosaurus Rex should follow. So here it is: The mighty T-Rex!

I used my entry level cnc-machine on some 9 mm birch plywood and a spiral-toothed 1.5 mm flute to cut the parts. A 4 mm beech rod simplified the alignment of the parts and made the extremities movable.

A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create (even) smaller versions. Probably you could make a aluminum or brass version and screw the parts together to get tiny key fob.

You can visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Toys/Animals for more animals.

title: Lazy Susan horizontal spool holder for cake tin drybox
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a filament drybox but don’t have room for a massive one. All the smaller dryboxes seem to be flat so I needed to make a way to dispense filament with the spool on its side.

The solution is a Lazy Susan made with a simple 6202 bearing that I had kicking around. I’ve used the 2RS (2 rubber seals) type because the seals provide enough friction to stop the spool rotating and unravelling.

Simply print both parts, assemble onto the bearing and rest the spool on top!

I did consider making centring rings for different sizes of spool but there’s no need – it works fine as it is.

Shared as a thank you for all the excellent designs given by others that I've made and enjoyed...

description.text:
Dice for a pokemon board game (+mathing regular K6 dice) rounded or square.

Designed in three versions:

  • for dual extrusion/multi material printers
  • for hand painting (0.5mm emboss)
  • for gluing 3d printed color inserts (1.0mm emboss)
    Pick a version that suits you best.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Dice inserts are very small and flat (0.8mm) for the best result slow down a lot. I was printing at 20mm/s and at times it was too fast in my opinion.

As for dices, just use your regular settings. The only thing you may tweak is the first layer height - use the same height as for rest of the print.

If you have a hot bed with a nice flat surface like glass/PEI sheet/etc. consider printing inserts mirrored so the nice and glossy surface will point up on the dice.

If you have a dual extrusion or multi material 3d printer then you are probably good to go without any post processing. But with painting or inserts a lot of patience, steady hand and caution is required. You'll need a fine tweezers, fine brush or toothpick, paints / glue.

Feel free to copy and edit thingiverse project of these dices

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3NjL4uBK9Xg-pokedice

Regular dice:

NOTE: If using Simplify3d, you might see a red disc in the middle of the cylinder. (No other software shows this). If so, you can click (on the menu) Mesh->Separate Connected Surfaces. This will fix it (before printing). Otherwise a very hairline thin layer appears in the middle of the cylinder (can be removed easily afterward).

LP Style Guitar for printing on CR10 size bed (300mmx300mm). Scale all OBJs to 2540% in Cura. I modeled in inches and this resolves the unit size conversion. Print for strength.
I used 3mm walls and 50% triangle infill in Cura. The neck shim was the only thing I printed at 100% infill. There are Left Handed (Marked LH) and Right Handed Parts (RH).
I am left handed so that's what I made. Print parts laying flat. Thingiverse shows them vertical for some reason.

This is a LONG print. The front section of the body was 82.5 hours. The other body
sections were around 42 hours each. With this in mind I made the whole top
swappable so you can print different tops with out having to reprint the body sections.

I used about 2 rolls of black PLA (Tainse Brand) and less than half a roll of the Army Green. I plan to model additional tops in the future. Because this was a simple flat top the pick ups
may seem a little low. Adjust or raise them as you see fit.

Scale length 24-3/4" is for a 22 fret necks. Amazon sells a Kmise neck for ~$45. That is what I used. I got the tuners, bridge and neck plate from Amazon too.

Get the Kwick Plug wire harness and pickups from GFS (Guitar Fetish) and you won't have to solider anything.

IMPORTANT: I made the body 1.5" to save time and filament. Most neck screws will be too long and will go through the neck at this depth. Use shorter screws. I used some short dry wall screws I had.

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Print Bed GoPro Corner Mounts

description.text:
Printrbot Simple Metal Print Bed GoPro Corner Mounts!

Two mounts made for the ability to decide between 2 different viewing angles for your Printrbot Simple Metal and GoPro Camera and/or other creations using GoPro style Mount & Connections :-).

One GoPro mounts designed to seat your camera or other creations at a 45 degree angle.

A second mount designed to seat in the same fashion, at a 30 degree angle.

The 45 or 30 both work in the very same way, though one may be better than the other, depending on the size of your Printrbots print bed. The stock beds are more square, so a 45 degree mount is adequate for the bed. The larger upgrade kit beds are more rectangular in design, so using a 30 degree mount allows you to see and capture the entire print bed in frame, rather then having the end cutoff from frame with the 45 degree mount!

I created these Mounts for my Printrbot Simple Metal in order to modify and attach my Octopi Rig design's Logitech c170 GoPro camera mount to the print bed. I have discovered that having the camera attached to the print bed creates a much more stable & static view of the printing process for generating time lapse style recordings.

With my OctoPi Rig, the camera sits in front of the printer. Although it has a clear view of the printing process, the video time lapse generated is very unstable. As with this setup, you see the print moving back and forth constantly, and inevitably end up with a very unclear, unfocused, & skipping view of the print being generated.

This approach provides a much greater pleasant experience for the time lapse generated of the printing process. As the camera is attached to the bed, it can clearly focus on the print being generated, while completely unaffected by the movement of the print bed. Creating a much better time lapse overall in a static position relative to the print being generated!

I will also post these models into a new Thing listing called "Printrbot Simple Metal OctoPi Rig, (Link: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2813736 ), as I created these models and a newly changed case for the PI, in order to make a more practical version of my OctoPi Rig to work with my Printrbot Simple Metal much better!

Happy Printing & Enjoy !

title: Crank for cold roll laminator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I'm pretty bad at applying PEI etc. to build plates and when looking for tips stumbled upon a video or two of a cold roll laminator being used and was like I NEED THIS. Ordered one on Amazon, the crank handle mine came with was an injected part that arrived cracked from the metal insert for the handle. Modeled a super simple one in Fusion 360 as a test, decided to model a more "traditional" looking one with spokes and built in threads since the crank's center metal insert was not removable.

Printer:

MonoPrice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.16mm layer

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Rotate to lie flat. I used 3 perimeters and 20% honeycomb infill in Slic3r Prusa edition, basically increase perimeters and infill for part strength. The layer resolution was to make sure the modeled in threads came out good, but slightly higher might still work (using 0.4mm nozzle).
I suggest threading in all the screws before installation, if your nozzle is wider than 0.4mm than I'm not sure how well the set screw threads will come out.
Fusion 360 and calipers. The crank itself is 120mm diameter, shaft hole is 12.25mm diameter, the handle thread is M8 and set screws threads are M5.
I may redesign this with thicker spokes or reduce the need for support material like I did with my simple version.

description.text:
This is a hinged version of my "Purse Hook for Audi TT RS (2012)." The hinge allows the hook to fold up out of the way when there are passengers in the backseat of a sedan.

I used M6 heat-set inserts (https://www.mcmaster.com/#94180a371/=178412o) to add threads to the base ("Base Half (Heat-set inserts).stl"), but I've provided an alternative piece with integral M6 x 1 mm threads ("Base Half (Threaded).stl").

The Mounting Face clamps to the Base Half using two M6 x 1 mm x 20 mm cap screws (https://www.mcmaster.com/#91292a137/=17841eu) and 12 mm O.D. M6 washers (https://www.mcmaster.com/#93475a250/=17844va). The hinge pin is 6 mm (1/4") stainless steel or brass rod, 76 mm (3") long. I drew a plug to cover the hinge-pin hole, but never printed it. Instead, I filled the hole in with Bondo before I painted the whole thing matte black

The design uses 1/8" x 3/8" rare earth magnets (e.g., https://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=D62-N52) to keep the hook folded, but I discovered they aren't needed—friction keeps the hook in the folded position just fine.

Notes:

I used an 0.6 mm nozzle (0.75 mm line width) with 10 bottom and top layers and 5 perimeters to print this in carbon-fiber nylon.

Finishing

After sanding the parts smooth (starting with 120 grit and working up to 400 grit), I primed using a catalyzed epoxy primer to seal the nylon and Eastwood's "Contour" to fill the print lines, then finished in jet black 2k acrylic urethane topped with 2k matte clear coat. Wet sand the epoxy and polyester Contour sealer with 220 and 400 grit and dry sand the color coat with ≥1000 grit before clear coating. If your shop is less dusty than mine, you can skip sanding the color coat, which is the approved automotive technique. If you use automotive finishes WEAR AN APPROVED RESPIRATOR! Catalyzed finishes are very toxic if breathed in.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed these in launch position with a 10 perimter attached skirt and support under the fins and edge of the body tube and launch lug.

description.text:
Two rocket variants using 13mm motors. Both eject the motor. The straight fin rocket is more stable based on open rocket calulations but both seem to work well. I've included pictures of the calculations from open rocket. I had one fail on impact at landing as shown in the picture. I used Estes A10-3T engines for launch. It will probably work with 1/2 A3T-2 although I did not try it. It will probably NOT work with 1/4 A3T-3.

Warning

These do not tumble after ejecting the motor and so fall nose down with a good deal of velocity. I would anticipate potentially serious injury if struck by the rocket so make sure you consider the launch rod angle, wind direction, etc to maximize safety. You will not be able to see these when they fall.

title: Assistive device for using disposable drinking cups

description.text: This is a holder for a disposable cup to help people with prosthetic limbs or limited grip strength to be able to drink from a disposable cup (one without a handle).  The cup fits into the holder.  The handle is shaped so that it is easy for a hand to slide in and out with ease.  The holder fits snuggly around the cup to prevent the cup from moving.  This is important for people that cannot grasp a cup without a handle or with handles too small to fit the prosthetic limb through.

• Download two files (one file for the handle and one file for the disposable cup holder).

  • Scale x and y or Z to make a version to fit any type of disposable cup.

  • Print each out.

  • Glue ("weld" with cyanomethacrylate glue) handle to holder.
    • We used an UP!3D printer on Draft mode (fast) in ABS plastic. This project was undertaken in association with the Center for Parabiotics Experimentatl Pathology Research Team (7/1-8/31) under the supervisoin of Dr. R. Siderits

author: mfinn

description.text: This is a storage unit for 3DS and DS games. The design is based off of Elitecgi's "Question Block Nintendo Switch Game Cartridge/Micro SD Card Holder" but with some minor tweaks. The cube is 1.5x larger in all dimensions, and the cube holds 3DS cartridges.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/l76fjLdkIUS

Bouchon rétroviseurTRIUMPH street tripple

This is my Mini CoreXY 3D printer that I designed to use a bunch of old parts I had laying around. This printer features...
---A compact design
---CoreXY kinematics
---Sturdy build
---High quality Misumi linear motion parts
---RADDS/Due 32-bit electronics
---TMC2130 and RAPS 128 stepper motor drivers
------Sensorless Homing
------Silent Movement
------1/256th stepping rate
---0.9Deg XY Steppers for high resolution movement
---24v Power for smoother stepper movement
---Dual Z axis bed leveling
---BLTouch bed leveling
---Dual Lead screws for superior stability
---Titan Bowden Extruder
---v6 Hotend
---Dual fan part cooling
---Laser cut acrylic electronics enclosure

This printer is still a work in progress. I have the printer mostly built and expect to finish building, configuring, and tuning it by the end of march. I have previously rebuilt one of my printers with parts I designed but this will be my first printer I designed and built from scratch. I expect it to print with extreme quality. I will update this page with my progress, and eventual videos of the printer printing upon completion. A complete parts list, a tutorial, and a marlin config are in the works as well. Most of the parts are finalized.

All parts were designed in AutoCad 2018. As stated this printer was designed to mostly use parts I had laying around. But my goal was still to make it cheap, sturdy and very very high quality. Nylock nuts are used everywhere possible for minimal maintenance and sturdy composition. All parts were printed with high glass transition temperature plastics so the printer could be enclosed. Most of the pieces were printed in either CPE, Colorfab XT, or PCTG plastic. The feet however were printed with ninjaflex. Most parts were printed with 100% infill, or 40% for the corners. The printer will run marlin, as I believe it to be most compatible with the features used in this build.

Full Size Adjustments

Because this printer was designed to use old parts I had laying around, it does not print to the full size of the print bed as I was bottle necked by the length of my extrusions. However, none of the printed parts in this design need to be adjusted should anyone build my design and expand it to print a full 200mm^3. To print to this size you would need...
---8x 2020 Extrusions, 315mm Length
---4x 2020 Extrusions, 370mm Length
---2x 2020 Extrusions, 330mm Length
---2x 10mm Dia Smooth Rod, 308mm Length
---2x 8mm Dia Smooth Rod, 260mm Length
---4x 8mm Dia Smooth Rod, 380mm Length
---2x T8 Lead Screw, 358mm Length
Pictures of current build are forthcoming.

I build two ships for son and nephew. The models are greatly prepared by Vladyka model Czech Republic http://www.vladykamodels.net

But for convenience and because I'm doing two boats at a time so I print some useful pieces for simplifying and perhaps improving models.

I'm sure just out of the box I could build the model, but why not make fun of it.

I draw in Fusion360.

More photos from the building will be published.

title: Plant Watering Bulb for Vase Mode

description.text:
Running low on my first spool of filament, I wanted to create a watering bulb that would do the job with very little plastic, and print quickly enough for a small garden. Ideally, a vase mode print. I designed this watering bulb to be watertight when printed with vase mode, so I tried to stay away from steep curves. This is why this bulb has a distinct low-poly, keeping the layers not too steep.

I designed this in 3DS Max because I know it more than any other software.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 to 0.3 for 0.4mm nozzles

Infill:

n/a (vase mode)

Notes:

Print in vase mode. I would recommend lower resolutions for increased watertight-ness. 0.2 to 0.15 in my own prints resulting in a totally sealed container.

I printed mine in PLA but any rigid plastic will do.

Make sure the print is air-tight.

Post print, blow into your completed bulb to check for escaping air. If even a little bit can escape, seal it up with something. Something like spray paint will do just fine. It's important that the print won't leak air. If air can come in, then air will be able to displace the water much faster, which will result in the water leaking out much faster than the intention of the bulb.

description.text:
I am currently taking a digital fabrication and design class at UW Milwaukee and this is what I designed for our coat hook project. For the final Coat Hook I have painted it pink.

The coat hook has a compartment on the inside, ideally for storing keys, bus pass, or mittens in the winter. There is also room to hang a bag or something on the base of the hook while the coat goes over the top.

This design is a part of a larger project I am working on which involves creating queer designs of everyday objects, such as coat hooks. Here I am referencing the pink triangle. I decided to keep my design more minimal and functional, because those are important to me in considering household design. This would be my version of a basic queer coat hook for my queer home. At this point I am working on creating a modified version of this coat hook that changes the proportion and angle between the small triangle base that attached to the wall and the final larger triangle profile that sticks out.

title: PHOTO FRAMES FOR STAND UP OR WALL DISPLAY

description.text:
Here is a simple way to display 4x6 or 5x7 photos. The frame is hidden behind the photo so the photo seems to float without the distraction of a visible frame.
The set of files includes 4x6L and 5x7L for stand up landscape, 4x6Pand 5x7P for stand up portrait, 4x6W and 5x7W for wall mount. Also there are files for an optional 'tree' that can support 3 4x6" W frames in portrait or landscape orientation.

The Wall mount can be used in portrait or landscape orientation. A common push-pin will just fit between the frame tab and the picture. To mount, push on the picture and the force will be carried through to the pin.

Pictures can be mounted to the frame with double face tape or with the small clips. To use the clips, put the picture face down on a table with one edge extending off the edge of the table. Position the frame on top, hold down firmly, and slide the clips over the edge of frame and picture.

The display tree is optional way to display the pictures. It has 4 parts; all parts are sized to fit within a 7.5x7.5" (190x190mm) square because that is the biggest many printers can make. The upper and lower parts are connected by a splice plate with the intention that the pieces be glued together. Frames are mounted to the tree with screws.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Late last year my small company moved into a new office. As part of it, we inherited the cubicle farm that was already there. I have no idea of the brand, but the tops were highly elliptical, rendering most of our existing top-mounted wall hooks useless. I searched Thingiverse for compatible designs, but I couldn't find anyone else using one with these particular dimensions. Fortunately, I had taken home a piece of the cube top shortly after move in and used it to design my own hook. Posting it here to share. Design is parameterized, though not sure how general it will be.

The top ellipse measures 42mm along the short axis and 86 mm across the long. These are designed to hook in opposite the coat hook and to snap in with gentle pressure. The hook top locks in and the small gap between the hook and the main coat hanger arm allows space to lay flush against the slightly protruding cubicle wall.

The hanger itself is beefy. I cannot say for sure how much weight it will hold, but I've loaded a couple of heavy winter coats on top of it without any deformation. The hook itself is long enough to hang a pair of headphones and the raised tip keeps them from sliding off easily. I've made several of these for my coworkers and they all think they are solid and a great improvement over the thin plastic hangers from our old office. One coworker has asked if I would use this design to make a white board marker hanger for him. I may try to remix this into that design in the future.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

This prints on its side in roughly 6 1/2 hours on my machine at these settings. 30% infill us used to beef up the hook. I don't generally print higher than that as the increase in strength achieved is minimal compared to increase plastic use. Supports are required to print the hook portion, which is smaller than the main hook body. I recommend printing this in the orientation shown for the best strength of the final product.
Remove supports with a pair of pliers, lightly sanding if desired. I generally found if I removed them while the bed was still warm, they came off easily and with minimal scarring on the hook.

Print the chair frame and fabric separately in two separate colors.
You can then snap-fit the fabric onto the chair - Each of four corners of the fabric has a small dimple, which accepts a corresponding pin on the frame.

The chair frame has in built hinges, just remove it carefully after printing. There is sufficient clearance between the chair legs to prevent them from getting fused, but if they do you can gently pry them apart by hand.

The fabric also has in-built hinges, it will be little tight just after printing, but will become loose after you flex it.

The incline of chair is adjustable with 4 notches.

This is designed to hold a Samsung Galaxy S7 (Edge preferred) horizontally with a slot on the side for you to slide your charging phone into the holder. There is also a window at the bottom so if you have your phone on "night-time mode," you can see the clock through it.

This is ideal for bedtime when you want to go to bed but you also want to use your phone for a little longer. You mount this to your wall using double-sided sticky tape, or similar adhesives, next your bed and outlet, so it can charge and be an active clock when you decide to sleep.

I found what features I wanted to have.

I measured my phone and the features (e.g. the clock and charging port)

I literally made a box with holes.

title: Beard Air System  Air Tube Holder For The Duet Smart Effector, Motor Mount & Electrical Cap

description.text:
The Beard Air System Air Tube Holder is a remix of Zesty Tech's Berd Air tube holder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2453322).
I keep breaking the Zesty's air tube holder so I came up with this design after 16 different design changes. The vertical tube holder is a little thicker and I moved it to the back side of the Smart Effector. The Vertical tube holder is 8.5mm off center to line up with the hot end. There is a slot in the tube holder for a zip-tie to help secure the aluminum tube.

The Berd Air motor power contacts are exposed and I was thinking a bit about safety. I made this cap that fits tight and has openings for the wires and cooling.

The Berd Air Motor mount came from here: https://repables.com/r/777/

description.text:
The Coleman 25 Qt Party Stacker Cooler is a popular container for Sous Vide in the Kitchen. The standard recipe is to drill a 2 3/8" hole in the corner of the lid, which will hold an Anova immersion heater.

This thing has two parts. (1) A support ring which will support the Anova at a height such that there is a 2mm gap between the bottom of the Anova and the top of a standard tray rack in the bottom of the cooler. (2) A plug to go in the hole when storing the cooler.

The design is in OpenSCAD and the source and resulting STL is provided.

description.text:
As a lover and frequent user of tea, I found that I needed a place to put used tea bags, infusers, strainers, and spoons. This is that solution.

This is designed to hold a single tea bag for cooling purposes to then be disposed of. There is also a slot to hold a spoon for mess-free kitchen counters, and it can hold a variety of tea infusers and strainers in place of bags for the loose leaf lovers.

The holder is also designed to mimic the shape of a tea leaf for a little added decor.

Notes:

I have not printed this yet; it is out of commission at the moment.

Need for Tea

After measuring varies tea bags, strainers, infusers, and spoons, I designed a leaf-shaped bowl and then put a slot on the end that would be capable of holding at least one of each at a time.

title: Ludwig Y4 Miniquad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
March 6, 2018 - Added BatHolder2s, fits a 2s 350mah lipo.
March 5, 2018 - Added BasePlate3mm and SidePlateFor3mm, updates going forward will most likely be to this version.
Feb 28, 2018 - Added BasePlateV2, adds some motor protection

Work in progress and will probably change! Upside, this is a pretty quick print since it is entirely flat plates.

This is Ludwig, a Y4 micro quad. Requires being printed out of a rigid material, particularly the bottom plate. I used Carbon Fiber PLA, worked awesome. Designed around 1104 motors with 3" props, and a 2s lipo. Intention is to get a decent flight time for cruising around the yard.

Use 15mm m2.5 standoffs for assembling the body.

Current components as Pictured:
HGLRC ZEUS F4 Aio
1104 7500kv motors
3020 Props
2s 350mah lipo
FrSky R-XSR

1:10 scale small-block chevy exhaust headers. Designed to mount to RC sprint car bodies.

Picture shows a comparison between an off-the-shelf injection-molded piece compared to the 3D printed part. The one shown was made with PLA on an Anet A8, but you may want to use ABS or PETG to stand up to the rigors of RC car racing.

The Solidworks part file is included for those who wish to remix this.

I just purchased a Linksprite mini , and the machine doesn't come with a good way to hold your work piece so I drew these up really quick. I used PLA and find that they work well with the T-nuts that come with the machine.

V2.0 pleasse see list of changes / improvements at end

A friend asked me to make some steps for hisHO layout to connect the plat form to the ticket office.... and that was the full btief. it thus seemed obvious to come up with a modular system that would suit nearly any situation.

the modulws can either be pieced together using an stl editor or more realisticly printed as needed for your design and then glued together,

The design is loosly based around the passenger footbridge at St. Erth, UK. However, i deliberately avoided roo much detail such as rivets so that the bridge can be painted as concreet or metal (given the lack of breif)

Likewise the roof is optional and parts can be scaled as needed. in particular the stairs are designed to be easily snapped in half so that i can use them for my scratch build overhead station.

NB. Only the roof & stair sections (and possibly the upright, depending on your printer) need supports-

Be careful when removing rafts/ brims and supports

V2 Update

improved shape of stairs roof
moor detail on version(B) corner roof
easier conectivity using version (B) corner roof
Single corner base designrf
improved alignment throughout

this is a print in place item. i made supports to hold the roller from lifting during print (as happened to me). you need be careful removing these and regular supports to ensure clean operation. place supports in slots for tube in front. and place supports under roller, near the supports i made. take a razor and carefully cut between knob and frame to help loosen supports there. the end opposite the knob must be squeezed to push out the roller, so you can clean in the area of the frame where the ratchet action happens. clean the knob in the area around around the ratchet area to ensure clean operation.
also rotate the model 90 degrees to place it flat on the supports i made.
