author: ctilley79

print_settings.Notes:: Print in the orientation shown and no supports are required.

description.text:
28BYJ-48 Mechanical Actuator #2

I thought it would be cool to see what kind of Mechanical Actuators we could make using the 28BYJ-48 stepper motor and mostly 3D printed parts. The 28BYJ-48 is the motor that comes with most Arduino kits. It's a 5v dc motor with a max rpm of 15 and is capable of around 4 oz force/in of torque. You can get these motors with the driver for around $2 each.

Direct Drive Inverted Dovetail Stepper Slide

This is a remix of the original dovetail design. This version has the gib built into the carriage instead of the ways this allows for longer travels as the gib moves with the carriage. Accuracy is reduced slightly as the backlash of the original version can be adjusted all the way along the way instead of just at the moving carriage.

=====================================================================

Dovetails slides are not really good at long travels or fast speeds but they are very accurate with the addition of a gib to the dovetail way allows for adjustment of the clearances between the ways and the carriage reducing backlash. This is a direct drive slide as the drive screw is clamped directly to the shaft of the stepper motor. The downside to this is that there is a lot of slop in the motors shaft as it’s not designed to carry an axial load. The v3 slide I plan on making will address axial loads as it will use an integral bearing flange.

The max RPM of the motor is 15, the pitch of the drive screw is .5" so the max speed will be 7.5" per minute. The motor can move roughly 7 lbs of weight on the carriage. The load capacity and life cycle can be greatly increased by using grease on both the drive screw and the way. The video shows the repeatability of the slide, after running for a few hours it was only .01" off location.

The mounting holes on the base, carriage, and the endplate all match up so multiple slide assemblies can be bolted together to make a two or three axis cartesian system.

=====================================================================

Required Components

M3 Nut (12x)
M3 SHCS x 6mm lg. (4x)
M3 FHCS x 10mm lg. (2x)
M3 SHSS x 16mm lg. (3x)
28BYJ-48 Stepper Motor

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hzth1Ne-0JE
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6R109NuJiwY

description.text:
Popper Licious

Preferred scale: 150% with 3 walls and 3 top and bottom layers at 0.3 and 10% honeycomb infill, this has given me the best results. The popper, when resting in the water, has to sit at an angle (see picture for reference). If you intend to use a bb for rattling, don't forget to pause the print to add it.

The 3 holes are designed to not come out as holes but to trick the slicer into adding material in that area so the eye screw has something to bite into. I personally drill the holes with a bit half the diameter of the eye screw and then use epoxy to secure it.

Poppers are my favorite type of lures and I decided to design my own, Features include:

  • Chamber for steel bb (rattler)
  • Scalable, you can print them at different scales to match the size of fish on your lake
  • Gills that shoot water as you pop it.

Everything you need to finish this lure:
Budget Treble Hooks

description.text:
Tired of having to store your flashlight diffuers separately and getting them lost? Here's your solution. Store your diffuser directly on the head of the flashlight. To use it as a diffuser, simply flip it around and reattach.

The sample flashlight diffusers are specific to the Thrunite T30, Thrunite 1A V3, and the generic zoom flashlight - the diffuser design can be modified for just about any flashlight with a head. One end of the diffuser is thicker (inside diameter) than the other end. This allows the diffuser to store directly on the head when inserted on direction and when flipped the other way, it only fits on a few mm onto the bezel, acting as a diffuser. To make the light into a full diffuser, cover the top hole with a piece of tissue paper or other covering (like duct tape).

Storage End Outer Diameter: 2mm thicker than inner diameter
Diffuser End Outer Diameter: Same thickness as storage end outer diameter.
Diffuser End Inner Diameter: just thick enough to catch tightly on the bezel and not slide onto the head. This end needs to also be long enough that it catches the bezel when diffuser is reinserted in "storage mode." Failure to make this piece long enough means that the diffuser could slide off.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

No supports and rafts needed.
Dquad Obsession Side Panel

This is a tenor version of the Japanese Taishokoto (or the Indian Bulbul Tarang / Benju, sometimes known as the "China Organ"). All of the levers and keys are 3D printed, the rest is made of wood.

I created this because I have a bulbul tarang which is more of a toy than an instrument--its range went from C5 to C7, which sounds quite tinny and toy-like. This tenor instrument is a whole octave and a half lower, going from G3 to C6, so it sounds more like a professional instrument. Consequently, this makes it much harder to play, since the lower strings are so far apart that proper fingering is almost impossible. This is normally acceptable on a guitar or other stringed instruments, but not for a keyboard setup. So build and play one of these at your own risk.

The file name of each lever contains instructions on how many to print. The rest is up to you if you decide to build one. The process is fairly straightforward if you take a look at the pictures--just make a soundbox roughly a meter long, then put strings on it with tuning pegs (I used five strings in unison for a fuller, tremolo sound). Then it's best to use a pencil and a chromatic tuner to mark off where each key should go. Then mount a half-inch piece of wood onto the back-top edge of the soundbox and use a Dremel Multi-Max tool to cut out a spot for each of the lever bases. Then glue all of the levers together. Then just glue each completed lever in place, and you're done.

Some other notes:

  • Print each piece individually for best results.
  • You may need to use a heat gun to bend some of the levers in place for best pitch
  • I used a heat gun to widen each hole at the end of each lever slightly so it snugly fit each cylinder
  • Never leave the instrument in a hot car, especially if using PLA, as the whole thing could melt out of place
  • I made a QuickSteel molded cast of the two "string base" pieces since, if I used the original plastic pieces, the strings might cut right through them if the pieces got warm enough to be malleable. I recommend doing this to be safe
  • I originally intended to wind my own metal springs for each key, but then I found out that my 15 year old braces rubber bands did the trick just fine! I used the American Orthodontics brand "Steller's Sea Lion" 1/4" 6.4mm gauge rubber bands. I recommend using them instead of springs, simply because they're still highly elastic after all these years, with no signs of cracking. Here's a link to buy some (if you didn't suffer the torment of having to wear braces): https://www.amazon.com/pack-Orthodontic-Elastics-Bands-diameter/dp/B002GCNZMU/ref=sr_1_1_a_it?ie=UTF8&qid=1519612175&sr=8-1&keywords=braces+sea+lion+rubber+bands&dpID=41eiGtJMz9L&preST=_SY300_QL70_&dpSrc=srch

Message me if you have any questions!

title: Titan Aero and EZABL mount for CR10

description.text:
This is to attach a Titan and a TH3D EZABL bd levelling system to the CR10 X carriage. This will work with a volcano, or any other v6 with or without the Aero, and the 0.9degree E3D motor. If you don't use the Aero you will need to modify your Z-axis limit switch.

If you're here, you like me have decided to upgrade your CR10 to a direct drive arrangement, or;
-You are sussing it out as you have been convinced this is the best way forward for print quality improvements
-You have been bullied into joining the E3d band-wagon to stop being beaten up in the playground
-You are a habitual printer modifier (seek professional help, it's cheaper!)

If you're like me a little bit from each of the above reasons is the truth.

The big reason for me being here though is a really big reason, like a desk filling, child eating, power consuming, money burning, 500x500x500 reason.

I love my Cr10s exactly as it is bowden and all, but a 0.4mm nozzle will not cut it on the S5 (I'm pretty sure to release such a product with a 0.4mm nozzle proves Creality are into sadomasochism.)

Anyway, there are a number of CR-10 mounts that are available on thingiverse....

"This is my mount. There are many like it, but this one is mine.
My nozzle is my best friend. It is my life. I must master it as I must master my life.
Without my mount, my nozzle is useless. Without my nozzle, I am useless. I must goo my nozzle true. I must goo straighter than the original glass plate that was trying to kill me. I must goo before it warps and lifts." 3d Printerperson's Creed.

The reason I remixed the mount by KRushin is that is was so close!!! But the E3D slim motor wouldn't fit, and It had a part cooling fan design that wouldn't work with a Volcano.

All I have done is.. Moved the EZABL mount out a bit(6mm) to fit the slightly larger E3D stepper motor and removed the part cooling fan.
will probably use the "CR-10 fang like cooler for titan aero + volcano" by pballerss.

Note*
I'm printing it right now and my Titan/Aero/EZABL/Volcano parts haven't arrived yet.
So print at your own risk, I will update when the print finishes and when my assembly begins.

EZABL : https://www.th3dstudio.com/product/ezabl-kit-ez-connect-version-cr-10-abl/?attribute_power-adapter-type=USB

Titan(clone): https://www.th3dstudio.com/product/th3d-titan-extruder-31-gearing-bowden-or-direct-1-75mm/

AERO for Titan : http://aus3d.com.au/E3D-Titan-Aero-Upgrade-Kit

Stepper for Titan: http://aus3d.com.au/e3d-titan-motor

The amount of infill you choose will be dependent upon your individual psychological comfort zones. Probably anything above 25% will be fine. I plan to bolt a volcano under this thing and push 1.2mm of goo for long periods of time on the s5, so I went 100% infill.

author: Ximno

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
details here: https://imgur.com/gallery/v3V6D/

Summary from the imgur post:

Finished picture first. This is my sand blasting cabinet. It's a Harbor Freight special, with a long list of upgrades. The latest upgrade is a little better dust collection system. The original Harbor Freight design had the vacuum on the left side of the cabinet, and there is a hole on the back, in the top right corner. Air flowed from right to left, taking the dust with it. The problem is that the gun for the sand blaster shoots into the left side (because I'm right handed). This resulted in a pretty good portion of blasting media being sucked up by the vacuum, and wasted.

I fixed this problem in 2 ways, this post details how. First, I reversed the direction of air flow. Now I'm sucking air out of the back of the cabinet, in the top right corner. Second, I added a dust deputy. This is a cyclone style dust separator, which drops the dust down into the white bucket. This way, I can just empty the bucket back into the blasting cabinet in case it does still suck up some media.

I used an inexpensive vacuum cleaner. It will be dedicated to this job, and if it doesn't end up being big enough, I can always buy something bigger, and use this around the shop. In order to get everything to attach to each other, I 3d printed several parts.

Link to the dust deputy: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002JP315K/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Link to the vacuum cleaner: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003M2F7NI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: Wheelchair-Mounted Dog Treat Dispenser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a dog treat dispenser which can be mounted on a wheelchair, allowing people with limited hand mobility or dexterity to easily reward their assistance dogs for good behaviours. The device can also simultaneously actuate a handheld clicker, making it possible to employ the "clicker method" of dog training used by many organisations. The device is made of exclusively 3D printed parts in order to eliminate any potential difficulties sourcing components, and does not require any electronics. This makes it both easy and affordable to replicate.

The project was originally undertaken as part of the TOM Global (Tikkun Olam Makers) Innovation Challenge. I also worked with several great people associated with PADS (Pacific Assistance Dog Society), a non-profit organization in Vancouver, BC that breeds, raises, trains and supports certified assistance dogs. The good folks at Tinkerine were kind enough to help with prints for design testing.

This version is functional, but could still use some polishing. I hope to continue refining the design of the treat dispenser based on user feedback in order to make it as practical and easy-to-use as possible.

Youtube videos which show the device in action:

  • https://youtu.be/7nEjaSM5ihQ
  • https://youtu.be/3KIXZ9USlOU

author: KenMaclean

description.text: I made the Death Star easier to print without supports (any droops are on the inside!) and hollow to save a bunch of time and material.

This is a stackable holder for sunglasses (or any kind of glasses) that can be mounted to a wall, or simply stacked in place and left freestanding.

Assembly is simple. Print the armature as many times as you like, then slide the top tab into the bottom receiver. The holes should align perfectly for mounting. Use a screw to attach the holder to the wall. The end of the armature has a receiver for a cap. Leave the cap off if you need to slide your screwdriver down through the armature to attach it to the wall.

Once you've got it screwed in, use the cap to finish the appearance. There is also a plug if you want to round off the armature. The plug snaps into the center of the armature. Either way, fold the temples of your sunnies flat, then mount them on the armature just like it was a nose. Adjust the temples of your glasses to stabilize them on the armature.

This fire extinguisher bracket is designed for mounting the extinguisher to the top of my vehicle emergency kit. Other methods of carrying an extinguisher in a vehicle typically require some sort of mounting hardware that installs via drilling and inserting bolts into the vehicle itself. By mounting the fire extinguisher to the vehicle emergency kit, vehicle modifications are no longer needed. This design allows the fire extinguisher to go with the bag and into whichever vehicle.

The bracket allows the extinguisher to snap into place and does not allow the extinguisher neck to easily dismount without intentional effort.

The circles throughout the design are for weight savings. The 1* symbol comes from the military and first responder patch reminding them to be careful because they only have one "butt" to risk. Typically, you have no obligation to fight the fire...even if you are trained to do so. The phrase printed on the bracket is to remind the user to complete a situational assessment before attempting to fight a fire with a 2.5 pound extinguisher and to be safe while doing so.

Note: I found that the extinguisher gauge facing down could prevent it from being damaged from impacts. However, I did not think of that part prior so I made it with the gauge side up handle in the bracket, which holds it more securely. Depending on how you mount yours, you may need to reverse my design to have the gauge face down and have the handle in the bracket.

Last Note: The 3D printed mount does hold the extinguisher securely. However, out of an abundance of caution, this bag/extinguisher/bracket combination should be placed in the trunk so that no flying objects will be in the cabin should something come loose in a collision.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

If you make your own bracket for a different extinguisher, make sure to keep the same edges rounded as my design. Those rounded edges ensure that the bracket does not catch on other objects and also allows the bracket to rotate out of the way when the extinguisher is removed.

The bracket holder holes (for the zip tie) must be circular to facilitate the full range of motion required to get the bracket out of the way.
Picture showing gauge facing up but with the handle in the bracket

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8kai8kYJ0Cw

Warning: The following may be a bit confusing.

This car and its manufacturer are completely figments of my imagination. The manufacturer is called "WagenCorps" and is a joint project between Volvo, Subaru and Cadillac (none of which I own) devoted to the resurrection of the Station Wagon, which had gone extinct by the figment-of-my-imagination future which the car comes from. In this future, the auto industry is mainly devoted to the manufacture of flying cars known as "Air-Drivers", abbreviated to AD in model names. All of my futuristic car models come from this future. Annotated image of marque symbol is enclosed.

This model is named "Pontiac" in the tradition of naming car models after old, obscure or otherwise-discontinued automakers in the futuristic facet from which this whole futuristic-car business stems. Sorry, guys, Pontiac's dead. I based the front end on a '59 Bonneville.

I designed this one to be adjustable to other sizes of routers, vacuum tubing, etc. The .stl is for a 64mm router (the Harbor Freight trim router) and a 31mm inside diameter vacuum tubing. The magnets I used are 1/2" but that setting is also adjustable. The bottom piece that will have vinyl or brushes glued into it is uploaded now. Tonight I'll plan on getting some vinyl or brush material and some clamps.

If you are trying to download the .scad files and modify the parts, you'll need the hull.scad file from:
https://gist.github.com/hexagon5un/
Just make sure it is either in the same directory as my files or in your OpenSCAD libraries folder.

print_settings.Notes:: It is wise to test print smaller test block when printing polyurethane.  Printing with lower percentage infill will allow a high durometer filament behave like a lower durometer.

description.text:
Coil spring base automotive suspensions typically have a rubber rebound to limit motion when the maximum compression of the suspension is approached. On older vehicles these rebounds may have deteriorated over time. In this particular instance I find the "foamed polyurethane" rebounds on the rear suspension of my 1988 Merkur Scorpio to have virtually deteriorated. I experimented printing small test cylinders at different infill percentages to mimic the elastic consistency of the original material when printed with 90 durometer polyurethane filament. 30% seemed correct for my application, however you may wish to experiment for your application.

Realizing this is a wide application I made this a parametric model. However the defaults settings and the .stl included should be good for Sierra/Scorpio/Xr4ti. The SCAD file is pretty self explanatory.

The application is not limited to automotive suspensions. Rebounds for door stops could also be made for example.

Tronxy x5s

title: USING AN LDR SENSOR WITH ARDUINO

description.text:
Introduction

Hi Everyone, This is my 1st Arduino's tutorial video. In this video i am going to show you how to use a LDR or Light Dependent resistor to turn on and off another circuit or a LED.

Wouldn’t it be really cool if whenever a room gets dark, a light bulb automatically turns ON and eliminates the darkness? In this very simple project, I am focusing on eliminating darkness. You can even use this as an emergency lighting system.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1rltou-lzyQ

Step 1: Principle



The LDR is a special type of resistor which allows a lower voltage to pass through it (high resistance) whenever its dark and higher voltages to pass (low resistance) whenever there is a high intensity of light.

We are going to use a 10k resistor along with the LDR to create a voltage divider circuit. The varying resistance of the LDR is converted to a varying voltage that the analog pin of the Arduino will then be using in its logic.

Step 2: Hardware Requirement


For this very simple DIY Arduino project we need:

  • a breadboard
  • an arduino uno/nano (whatever is handy)
  • LED (Light Emitting Diode)
  • LDR (Photoresistor)
  • A 10K Resistor for creating the voltage divider and a 220ohm resistor for the LED
  • Few breadboard friendly connecting wires
  • and a USB cable to upload the code to the Arduino

Step 3: Assembly

  • Connect the 3.3v output of the Arduino to the positive rail of the breadboard

  • Connect the ground to the negative rail of the breadboard

  • Place the LDR on the breadboard

  • Attach the 10K resistor to one of the legs of the LDR

  • Connect the A0 pin of the Arduino to the same column where the LDR and resistor is connected (Since the LDR gives out an analog voltage, it is connected to the analog input pin on the Arduino. The Arduino, with its built-in ADC (Analog to Digital Converter), then converts the analog voltage from 0-5V into a digital value in the range of 0-1023). - Now connect the other end of the 10K resistor to the negative rail - And the second (free) leg of the LDR to the positive rail

Pretty much this is what we need for the light sensing. Basic circuits like this can be done without an Arduino aswell. However, if you want to log the values and use it to create charts, run other logics etc. I will recommend an Arduino or ESP8266 or may be a ESP32 for this.

Now, as we want our circuit to do something in the real world other than just displaying the values on the computer screen we will be attaching a LED to the circuit. The LED will turn on when its dark and will go off when its bright. To achieve this we will:

  • Place the LED on the breadboard
  • Connect the 220ohm resistor to the long leg (+ve) of the LED
  • Then we will connect the other leg of the resistor to pin number 13 (digital pin) of the Arduino
  • and the shorter leg of the LED to the negative rail of the breadboard

Step 4: The Code


const int ledPin = 13;
const int ldrPin = A0;

void setup() {
Serial.begin(9600);
pinMode(ledPin, OUTPUT);
pinMode(ldrPin, INPUT);
}

void loop() {
int ldrStatus = analogRead(ldrPin);
if (ldrStatus <= 200) {
digitalWrite(ledPin, HIGH);
Serial.print("Its DARK, Turn on the LED : ");
Serial.println(ldrStatus);
} else {
digitalWrite(ledPin, LOW);
Serial.print("Its BRIGHT, Turn off the LED : ");
Serial.println(ldrStatus);
}
}

remixed_from.title: Shorter MOSFET Mounting Bracket for Monoprice Maker Select V2, Cocoon Create, Wanhao i3

title: Shorter (Z Axis - 6mm) MOSFET Mounting Bracket for Monoprice Maker Select V2.1, Cocoon Create, Wanhao i3

description.text:
Remix of patprint's remix of uwe999's remix of rawlogic's MOSFET mount to be shorter in the Z dimension from 8mm to 6mm. The reason I remixed it is because 8mm is taller than the stock standoffs in the maker select v2.1 control box. (6.8mm, 7mm at the closest ones, 7.34mm at the farthest. [yeah they're a bit uneven])

A 8mm part then has the effect of raising up the control board so it rests on the printed bracket so the SD card slot and the USB card slot was a tighter, fiddly fit. I speculate original designers intended this so the bracket is held under tension against the control board and firm and doesn't wiggle around.

That would have been technically functional but I'm anal about these kinda things, so I made my own 6mm version so the control board rests on the original level/height, so my access to the mini USB port and MicroSD card slot was stock and unimpeded. I chopped off the top 2mm in TinkerCAD.

Friction fit on the standoffs hold it in fine, and there is only < 1mm wiggle room anyways, plus that the control board only gets moved seldomly and doesn't vibrate, etc.

Dimensions are 7.05 cm by 10.92cm with height of 0.6 cm

Printed with 0.2mm layer height, adaptive layers in Cura 3.2 up to 0.3, 50% infill, and 3 shells, and a test run of Cura's "Ironing feature" which resulted in a nice surface.

MOSFET wiring info: http://3dprinterwiki.info/wiki/wanhao-duplicator-i3/di3-advanced-mods/heatbed-terminal-burning-fix-with-mosfet-board/

remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi Case with GPIO Access

description.text:
Case for Raspberry Pi.
Derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24945 but with dimensions that fit my Raspbery Pi more accurately.
Wanted to clarify- there were several things I modified:
1) Merged lincomatic's version with latest from Hans.
2) Made the micro USB power connector hole about millimeter taller- otherwise it didn't quite fit.
3) Shaved 0.5mm off from wall which is next to GPIO hole- otherwise it did not fit next to GPIO pins (the pins themselves did fit, but pins have a wider base).
4) also, moved SD card hole a bit. Card reader was in a way of case otherwise.
5) Made the case mating walls longer- otherwise they break too easy.

I'm planning to add two things to this case:
1) Some mechanism to better lock top and bottom together. I'm thinking of simple 0.5-1mm bits on outside of bottom wall and identical holes on the inside of top walls.
2) Vesa mounts.

title: CR-10 extruder knob with a differece

description.text:
An extruder knob with a difference this one will not slip on the shaft so easily.
The problem with plastic knobs is they have little strength where it counts and are generally designed to large. The result is they turn on the shaft
The knob doesn't need to be very large as the shaft turns easily anywhay, it also has an indicator point so you can easily see the knob turning good for when the extruder retracts.

You will see there are 2 thin slots under the knob this is where you hammer in 2 square pieces of metal plate 10mm by 10mm by about .5mm you can cut this out of a dog food can lid or something like that. Make sure the pieces are flat. Sit the knob upside down on a hard surface and just hammer the metal plates in
The steel plates add strength to the hole one for the flat to grip onto the flat on the shaft and one to strengthen the opposite side to the flat.
All plastic knobs need added strength like this note the flat on the shaft will line up with the pointer on the top of the knob helps when you push it on to know where the flat is

Hope this is useful

Peter from Key 3D

author: dutchmogul

description.text:
Introduction

Hi Everyone, I am back again with this new tutorial.

In this tutorial, I am going to show you how to charge a Lithium 18650 Cell using TP4056 chip utilizing the solar energy or simply the SUN.

Wouldn’t it be really cool if you can charge your mobile phones battery using the sun instead of a USB charger. You can also use this project as a DIY portable power bank.

The total cost of this project excluding the battery is just under $5. The battery will addup another $4 to $5 bucks. So the total cost of the project is some what around $10. All components are available on my website for sale for really good price, the link is in the description below.

https://youtu.be/SPpgMl_TeIc

Step 1: Hardware Requirement

For this project we need:

  • A 5v Solar Cell (make sure it is 5v and not anything less than that)
  • A general purpose circuit board
  • A 1N4007 High Voltage, High Current Rated Diode (for reverse voltage protection). This diode is rated at forward current of 1A with peak reverse voltage rating of 1000V.
  • Copper Wire
  • 2x PCB Screw Terminal Blocks
  • A 18650 Battery Holder
  • A 3.7V 18650 Battery
  • A TP4056 battery protection board (with or without the protection IC)
  • A 5 V power booster
  • Some connecting cables
  • and general soldering equipments

Step 2: How the TP4056 Work

Looking at this board we can see that it has the TP4056 chip along with few other components of our interest.
There are two LEDs on board one red and one blue. The red one comes on when it is charging and the blue one comes on when the charging is done. Then there is this mini USB connector to charge the battery from an external USB charger. There are also these two points where you can solder your own charging unit. These points are marked as IN- and IN+ We will be utilizing these two point to power this board. The battery will be connected to these two point marked as BAT+ and BAT- (pretty mush self explanatory) The board requires an input voltage of 4.5 to 5.5v to charge the battery

There are two versions of this board available in the market. One with battery discharge protection module and one without it. Both boards offer 1A charging current and then cut off when finished.

Furthermore, the one with protection switches the load off when the battery voltage drops below 2.4V to protect the cell from running at too low (such as on a cloudy day) - and also protects against over-voltage and reverse polarity connection (it will usually destroy itself instead of the battery) however please check you have it connected correctly the first time.

Step 3: Copper Legs

These boards gets really hot so I will be soldering them a bit above the circuit board.

To achieve this I am going to use a hard copper wire to make legs of the circuit board. I will then be sliding the unit on the legs and will solder them all together. I will put 4 copper wires to make 4 legs of this circuit board. You can also use - Male Breakable Pin Headers instead of the copper wire to achieve this.

Step 4: Assembly


The assembly is very simple.

The solar cell is connected to the TP4056 battery charging board's IN+ and IN- respectively. A diode is inserted at the positive end for the reverse voltage protection. Then the BAT+ and BAT- of the board is connected to the +ve and -ve ends of the battery. (That all we need for charging the battery). Now to power an Arduino board we need to boost up the output to 5v. So, we are adding a 5v voltage booster to this circuit. Connect the -ve end of the battery to the IN- of the booster and +ve to IN+ by adding a switch in between. OK, now lets have a look at what I have made. - I have connected the booster board straight to the charger however I will recommend putting a SPDT switch there. So when the device is charging the battery its only charging and not getting used

Solar cells are connected to the input of the lithium battery charger (TP4056), whose output is connected to the 18560 lithium battery. A 5V step-up voltage booster is also connected to the battery and is used to convert from 3.7V dc to 5V dc.

Charging voltage is typically around 4.2V. Voltage booster's input ranges from 0.9 to 5.0V. So it will see around 3.7V at it's input when the battery is discharging, and 4.2V when it's recharging. The output of the booster to the rest of the circuit will keep it's 5V value.

Step 5: Testing

This project will be very helpful to power a remote data logger. As we know, the power supply is always a problem for a remote logger and most of the times there is no power outlet available. A situation like that forces you to use some batteries to power your circuit. But eventually, the battery will die. Question is do you want to go there and charge the battery? Our inexpensive solar charger project will be an excellent solution for a situation like this to power an Arduino board.

This project can also solve the efficiency issue of Arduino when in sleep. Sleep saves battery, however, the sensors and power regulators (7805) will still consume battery in idle mode draining the battery. By charging the battery as we use it, we can solve our problem.

https://youtu.be/SPpgMl_TeIc

Thanks again for watching this video! I hope it helps you. If you want to support me, you can subscribe to my channel and watch my other videos. Thanks, ca again in my next video.
NGSS CCSS

description.text:
Video explanation and demo:
https://drive.google.com/open?id=1nIwGjZRPDQmxj1aetzTSWgPMWCK011gq
https://drive.google.com/open?id=1yX4b5AkGVXYH5YdZv6hcb0o3sI3BT0ma

A shift indicator for cable shifted FWD manual cars, specifically for a honda with vtec. If you don't like hondas, take your gripes elsewhere, or remix it to have the standard tree instead of "civic". I might upload a different version eventually...

Basically, the switches mount to a printed plate that is attached to the cable's sheath, and a small fin travels inside the plate attached to the cable and triggers 2 switches. Left/right cable grounds out the left, center, and right columns of LEDs, while the forward/backward cable sends 12 V to the top or bottom rows of LEDs. example, if the shifter is pushed left, the left column is grounded. If the shifter is then pushed forward, the top row is energized. The only LED with both a positive and a negative would be the top-left, which is first gear. etc.

Crude wiring diagram included, colors coordinate with "speedwire", a 9-conductor wire set often used in car amplifier and audio installations. Anything will work, just keep note of what goes where. Also, switch placement may vary based on which direction your cables move (mostly for left-right, since they transfer to a forward backward movement. My left shift actually translated into a forward cable movement, but this may not be true for all vehicles)

Hood for ease of viewing in daylight will follow soon. (Hood, or "Sun Shroud", regular and long versions added 3/7/18. Simply glue on after assembly.)

When playing DND, I sometimes forget if I've cast a spell that requires concentration in prior rounds, so I made a token that has a slider in that I can switch quickly when my concentration status changes... e.g. cast "Guidance", switch to yes... if I want to cast another spell that requires concentration, now I know I can just look at this thing and remember that I'd break the prior spell if I do.

Admittedly, this isn't something that our group pays super close attention too, but its still nice to try to keep the intent in mind.

Files:

  • Token_Concentrating.stl is the base piece with the text.
  • Token_Slider_v3.stl is the slider with just the textured top
  • Token_Slider_v4.stl is the slider with the textured top and a bar in the middle to get a quicker grip.

I'm pretty new to Fusion 360, so I'm sure there are better ways to have done this, and certainly other things that would nice to add/improve, but it does what I needed and I learned from it.

title: Ganoderma lucidum - Reishi / Lingzhi Mushroom 3D Scan

description.text:
A local herbalist found wild Reishi mushrooms in our area, I bought one at the local herb store. The structure of mushrooms has always fascinated me, I took this and using photogrammetry, made a 3D scan replica of it, for use in 3d printing, or otherwise.

ReishiV5.stl is the ideal one for 3D printing, it's already oriented the best way (I believe) for 3d printing, you might want to move it down the Z axis a little bit so that it cuts off the base a little bit, creating a flat surface.

reishi.obj, reishi.mtl and .zip file containing the reishitexture.jpg work together to give a fully colored model, based off the orginal photos. Photogrammetry does a hell of a good job figuring that out, the texture looks incredible, and might be useful for some project.

Some things to note, when I scanned it, I had it held up by a thick copper wire holder, and that transfered to the model it created. I altered and removed it in the .stl, but the obj, still has a little circle shape of copper wire holding the base of the mushroom up. Just be aware.

author: Gabeff

description.text: A Retropie controller that attaches to your desk chair at the location where the arm rest cushion screws in. This is designed for the Quimat Arcade Buttons, 8x 30mm buttons, 2x 24mm buttons.
I designed this to make my $20 lamp from target look a bit cooler. If you use the gcode file it should print in a couple of hours.

After much testing, it is complete. I present the Rotating Death star. you will need to print the Hex base, Z-gear and the Death Star Gear. The blank one if for remixes (detail below). I have been warned that this may cause layershifts on your prints. I have tested this for over 30 hours of prints, nothing bad has yet happened, it may even have fixed my Z-wobble alittle. There is good clearance between the Z-gear and the sides of the hole it is in, and the whole setup does not load your stepper much (nothing that would cause overheating or other problems). Thanks for giving this a look, if you print this do post it to the "I made one" it would really make my day! more versions coming in the future, a radar dish, gun turret, etc. do leave suggestions in the comments.

TO PRINT:
-Print the 3 specified files (for a more snug fit into the hex use a brim and cut it off, the residue will make it tight)
-Highly reccomend a few drops of oil between the Hex Base and Death star gear, most lubricants would be fine, cooking oil would even do in a pinch
-Put the Hex base and Death Star together (may Require some force depeding on your printer.
-install the two peices on your printer
-place the Z-gear on the 8mm threaded rod. i also reccomed a tiny bit of blue tack between the rod and the Z-gear for more of a grip (the grip is intentionally not strong so in the event that the gears somehow jam the rod will detach from the Z-gear and still spin freely)
-attach the z-gear to the 8mm rod and you have yourself a really cool printer!

To Remix:
cut a hole 10mm in diameter, 8mm deep in whatever you want to spin (the part that replaces the death star) and combine with the "Body Gear (Blank)". I like to use meshmixer. print the other two pieces and dont forget to mark it as a remix to i can see your work!

title: Knight w/Greatsword (28mm/Heroic scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
KICKSTARTER ALERT!

We're currently running a Kickstarter campaign for the extended range of our ScatterBlocks (quick-assembling miniature terrain), so drop on by and drop us a pledge if you want the full range. For those of you supporting us (or thinking about supporting us) on Patreon, all the rewards will go to our backers there as well (as we do with all our crowdfunding campaigns).

This miniature is a variant of the one that will be included in our new game, Wrath & Ruin (currently in development), a blend of simple miniature wargaming and physical boulder-throwing (check out the videos). We're pretty excited about this one, and would love to get others in on the play testing phase before we expand and go wider with the game. Kickstarter backers at the $25 level and Patreon supporters will get the play tester kit in March (after the current campaign wraps).

The Knight, like all the miniatures we're designing for this game, prints without the need of support material. We printed ours without a raft and at a .1 layer height with 10% infill.

Enjoy!

On my snapmaker I had a fault that I diagnosed to be a faulty heater. On fitting a replacement I decided to make an extension to the print head module so the cable would not be so tightly curved.
Designed using openscad - no rounded corners as I haven't worked out how to do those yet.

First off, this is one of the better designed things I've found on Thingiverse. For the most part everything fits together perfectly, screw holes are right where they should be, etc. The only real problems I had were:

1) battery cage didn't quite make contact
2) I didn't want to solder on a different charger

With those things in mind, I made some minor changes in that I removed the stock battery mount, in favor of attaching the battery directly to the mainboard, and I made an opening in the back shell so that the original connectors can be accessed.

One last issue I haven't addressed yet, the d-pad doesn't quite fit without being trimmed down, I'm experimenting with scaling the part to see if I can make it work that way.
(Edit: Scaling the d-pad to 90% seems to work well enough)

title: Cafflano Kompresso Funnel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I love my Cafflano Kompresso (http://www.cafflano.com/product_kompresso.php?TM=2)
It makes a great espresso shot. Only challenge was when I would transfer the fine grind coffee to the basket filter, it would spill everywhere. So I made a funnel that fits perfectly within the basket filter. After filling up, carefully twist the funnel as I pull it out of the basket before tamping and extracting an excellent crema.

I printed mine out of PETG - .2mm layer height - 1mm wall thickness - 20% infill - no supports

If you make one as well - please share a picture and let us know what material you printed it out of.

I do have a design for a v2 that is a little smaller on the funnel side if folks are interested - just let me know and I can post it. Have not printed it because I haven't needed to.

description.text:
This is a model of the coat of arms of the St. Catherine's College, a saltire ermine between four Catherine Wheels. St. Catherine's College is one of the constituent colleges of the University of Oxford in England.

The model was created by importing the image of the crest (found on google) and tracing the edges with simple extrusion and fillet using OnShape.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

Any

Notes:

For the details (e.g. edges of the wheel) to come out perfectly, the print resolution should be as high as possible. The model should be printed vertically on FDM 3D printers, if you choose to print flat on the print bed then the details won't be properly printed since many edges are less than 0.2 mm.

Thickness of the shield can be reduced depends on print bed adhesion. I have purposely designed the mode with a thickness of 10 mm so that when printed vertically, the model sits stably on the print bed.
Step 1: Import St. Catherine's College crest image from google Step 2: Trace the edges of the image and simply extrude Step 3: Fillet the edges as appropriate

description.text:
I really appreciate the start from Laen on the Pixel 2 XL model. My phone differed from the model in 3 ways which caused the case not to fit as snug as I wanted, which I've adjusted in my copy of the Fusion 360 project:

  • The fillet around the back face appears to be asymmetric. I modeled it as a chamfer first and then filleted one of the corners
  • The fillets for the four corners of the phone were 1mm larger on my phone
  • The volume down button was a few mm lower on my phone

I think also, my phone isn't quite as thick.

After adjusting these parameters, some of the features for the other cases broke, I adjusted them to remove the errors, but now I imagine they don't match @Laen's intent. But the new component "Yet Another..." that I added is the phone case you see here.

Fusion 360 model: http://a360.co/2ETpxUU

This is By Mao Casella, URL: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/3d-print-titanic-53905

This is my model Printed on Mini V2. & my 1st publish on Thingverse

I cut each piece of the hull in 2 so each color is 4 pieces, using Meshmixer. The stand is my own creation.. Will publish stand if there is want.

title: Air Arms .177 Auto Indexing Magazine Mechanism

description.text:
See misc notes at bottom for instructions.

(Will send new pictures ASAP)

Printer:

Prusa i3 - By 3dprintingstore.co.za

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%, Rectiliniar, Will work for 25% as well

Notes:

Used ABS, would probably work with PLA. Print in two halves (making sure that the inside of the mechanism is facing up) and then glue together with superglue. Use 33mm hooks (as displayed). Coil it up around the chosen axel (to form it to the correct internal diameter) and bend to desired shape. This takes a while to perfect, I'd buy 3 or 4 hooks to start with. The axel is of brass, 2mm on the one end, 2.6mm on the other, 12mm long. Can be replaced with a small nail of the same dimensions. The action keeps this axel captive so remember to put it in from that end. Used M3 bolts and nuts.

There's 3 arms included, the +5 one worked for me. I'll update it as necessary.

Included is all the STL files and .ipt files (Used Autodesk Inventor Pro 2018)

title: Loc-Line screw on magnetic base for helping hands

description.text:
I wanted to build a helping hands using my knock off Loc-Lines I got from Amazon. I designed this to screw onto the standard threaded base and hold a 1" x .125" magnet from Amazing Magnets.

I printed in ABS and this allowed me to put the magnet in (it's snug but easy enough to push in) and then use acetone to glue the 1.5mm cap on, if you use PLA, i suggest gluing the magnet in place and gluing the cap on to make it very secure (the magnet is rated to pick up about 48lbs and is $3.20ea.

The other end of the Lok-line I used an alligator clip that has threaded handle, I pulled one piece off the end and used a #8-32 screw to attach it to the Loc-line. I had to file down the other Loc-Line ball a little to allow them to snap back together. I also put heat shrink on the alligator clips to prevent scratching and help avoid making them a heat sync.

I then painted a 1/4" piece of steel plate and put some rubber feet on the bottom to use as my base (my workbench is wood) if your workbench is steel you can skip this and use them straight on your bench.

title: CD and Album holder wall mount

description.text:
These are music albums and CD holders that you can mount on the wall. I designed them so that I can have my music on display. They are simple, small and only weight about 2.5g each with 25% infill and NO SUPPORT NEEDED! There is a small square on the back (20mm x 12mm), just large enough to add double sided tape or blue tak to adhere to the wall.

I made 3 different sizes for various ablums.
One for thin albums "Album Holder - Small": 4mm gap
One for medium albums "Album Holder - Medium": 8mm gap
One for large albums like the plastic cases "Album Holder - Large": 12mm gap
Also, there is one designed to hold a single cd, no case "CD Holder"

IMPORTANT NOTE: These brackets have been designed to sit slim on the wall, meaning the cd's and album sit almost flush. Just enough incline to stop them from topping over. Where l have them, this is no problem. But if you are planning on putting it somewhere in a high traffic area "like a windy area", than it may tip over. That being said, for 2.5g of filament, why not give it a go :).

I hope you like, l know l sure do.

title: CR-10 Direct Drive extruder with integrated RSE-2

description.text:
Got another one. This time I took the beefed up direct mount and added the RSE-2 extruder onto it as a single unit. Lined everything up with Ross_K's carriage model and my own crappy representation of my MircroSwiss heatsink.

The Noclearance file is for you to add your own cutouts to clear whatever cooling solution you have. The fang file is already pre-clearanced for 2bedom's MicroSwiss fang.

Edit: Added FilamentSaver file. This one is to test attachment to the carriage, position of the outlet tube to line up with the heatsink Bowden, and sizing of the hole to receive the Bowden.

Planning on printing out a low infil PLA test part this morning to see if there are any problems before going all in with PETG.

Update 2/26: Printed out the FilamentSaver in Hatchbox white PETG. Seems to fit perfect except the hole for the bowden tube is too small. I'm measuring about 3.5mm when it was supposed to be 4.2mm. Don't know why it shrunk so much more than everything else but I'll play with it. Uploaded three MKII files, these have the bowden hole enlarged to 5.2mm from 4.2mm, a 120% increase to match the shrinkage encountered. I know it will probably bite me since the full versions are printed at a different orientation than what I printed the test.

Update 2/28: Added MKIII Fangclear file, fixed a small clearance issue with the left guide wheel. Also enlarged the hole for the bolt which holds this wheel on, was a little tight on my Filamentsaver model that I printed. Also added a cover for the RSE2 extruder with a drag chain attachment molded in. Hopefully it should line up well enough and not get in the way. Used stevenfayers Z chain links, I don't have a fixed end modeled yet. The hole in the direct drive mount is for a 20x20 heatsink on the stepper, by the way, I forgot to mention that. Added MKIII-BowdenIn file. Should be able to thread a 5mm pushlok into it, made hole 4.78mm.

Update 2/28: Printed out the MKIII Bowden version. I was right, enlarged the hole too much. 5.2mm in CAD came out 4.8mm on print. Still going to install it and make sure there's no other problems. Looks good just looking at it. Got some stringing and ugly places. Used Hatchbox white PETG.

author: stmorgan

title: Turbine v1 Sex Toy for Men
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Sex toy for men, along the same lines as a fleshlight.

There are two variants here, one for large format printers with the height to just print it, and the second one for normal / smaller 3d printers.

The small form-factor version is split into multiple parts, and has alignment pegs. Dry fit, all parts before assembly, and use appropriate glue for your filament to assemble.

Just a heads up, This may take quite a while to print depending on your settings, and how much finish work you're willing to do.

I would advise 0.15mm - 0.2mm layer height. Infill settings may be whatever you're comfortable with, and will print well, as these are fitted parts.

I would also suggest, if you do print this, be sure to clean it up very well, and smooth all the surfaces out. Take care to ensure the mating surfaces are particularly well fit, as to keep the silicone, or whatever from seeping out.

The holes around the perimeter of the base are sized for tapping 4mm screws to hold the base to the outer mold.
The central hole on the base is sized for tapping an 8mm screw to hold the core to the base.
The central hole at the top of the core is sized for tapping a 4mm screw and washer.

As i have not yet printed this, i have no recommendations beyond that already stated. I also want to point out, I am not responsible for any injury, or damages you may or may not suffer as a result of printing, or utilizing this mold.

All that out of the way. If you DO decide to print this mold out, i would be very interested in seeing the final print, as well as any surface preparations you make.

Enjoy
:)

-----[ Surface Preperation ]----

Before using this mold to create something that you might "use" on yourself. Be sure to use auto body filler, wood putty, or any other type of "filler" that sets up rigid, and non-porous. Then sand, polish, and smooth out all of the surfaces and seal it with a non--toxic, or food grade safe sealant..
Once you are ready to mold, be sure to use bees wax, or other non-toxic release agent over the entire mold surface.

releasing the silicone from the mold should be as easy as removing the fill, and base caps, and "unscrew" the core from the silicone. Once the core is removed, you can then proceed to removing the silicone from the outer shell.

Because the design of the mold is such to reduce silicone needed, proper preparation of the surfaces are CRITICAL to releasing the silicone from the mold!!

title: JDM License Plate Adapter - Subaru Legacy B4/GTB

description.text:
For my JDM subaru, I had to drill a hole in my license plate for it to fit. I know its probably illegle, but still better than holding it down with just one bolt. All the metal adapter I find costs over 20 bucks so I decided to design my very own adapter, it will give you about an inch of space to play around (27mm).
This Adapter allows you to put Canadian(or NA) License plate onto your JDM vehicle. It was designed for my Subaru Legacy B4/GTB. The bigger hole is for M6 bolt, a smaller M5 to hold the license plate, you will need a washer for it.
It will also work on any other car that has M6 screw for their license plate.

All you need is:

1of M5x10mm bolt, nut and washer (or lock washer)
1 of the adapter and spacer

How to install:

  1. Print one of the adapter and spacer, place the M5 nut in the T slot and install the adapter onto ur car, tighten it down.
  2. Loosely Install your license plate onto the adapter.
  3. Slide your license plate until you find the right position for other hole, and install the orginal screw with spacer behind the license plate.
  4. Tighten the M5 bolt once you have the other side installed.

PS:
I made the holes 0.2mm bigger because I did not calibrate my x y steps/mm on mine. However it should work no matter what.
If one doesnt work, print out two of them.

I also uploaded solidwork file if you ever need to change anything.
I am not a professional, if you find any problem with my design please let me know.
If you have any special request, leave a comment and I can try to customize one for you.

Solder the wires on the front side of the NeoPixel and put it up side down in de NestPixel holder.

Hold the NestPixel Ring on the wall and bring the wires trough the tube at the raspberry or ESP8266.

After that you pull out the wires of the Nest it self trough the hole in te middle.

Screw down the ground plate, with de NestPixel ring, on the wall. Connect the Nest wires and click on the Nest.

comments.text: Earsling - these are awesome and you're changing the entire 3d printing hobby for wargamers.  I hate to criticise, but the muskets are backwards.  When you're at the shoulder (musket in left hand, resting on the left shoulder) the barrel and hammer are on the outside and the trigger is on the inside.
comments.author: NW_Cdn

comments.text: Thanks for the comments - I wouldn't call that criticism, I'd call that constructive feedback. I remember pausing when I added the musket but think I was influenced by the the packet of figures at https://store.warlordgames.com/products/napoleonic-portuguese-line-infantry , which was the moment when I thought 'there's an awful lot of genericness about these figures' (and which reminds me I haven't put out my set of original stove-pipe shakos yet). Is that dodgy artistry, a Portuguese thing, or one of these endless debated issues? The safe option would be to genericise the stock, make the barrel and the woodwork the same length, and let the painters decide...
comments.author: NW_Cdn

comments.text: I've never seen that before - it's either some odd Portuguese thing or an artist's mistake.  There's lots of good sources for drill out there and I'm confident that British and French line would have the musket barrel out at the shoulder.  (Note that at the shoulder means on the left shoulder).  There's lots of good sources of drill out there in the reenactment community:
comments.author: Earsling

comments.text: Forgot to mention - thanks for the comments and references - I've changed the figures now, but haven't yet changed the .png's which will have to go on the tidy-up list
comments.author: NW_Cdn

comments.text: Thanks for updating the files.
comments.author: Earsling

comments.text:
Hey, great addition to the collection!
I can not print (or paint) them as fast as you're adding new units.
I'm looking forward for doing a few Russian units - there are so many possibilities with your designs!
Thank you for this new goodies.
comments.author: vizenz

comments.text: Painted them in the wrong order! Part 7 - Russian cavalry out soon (after I work out why the trumpeter had an arm coming out his back ?!)
comments.author: vizenz

comments.text:
The Tsars revenche for bad duty? Or maybe Chaos Russians? ;)
Your other Cavalry trumpeters have the same problem. But I will paint this up as some kind of trumpet case.
comments.author: Earsling

comments.text: Trumpet case - brilliant idea! Have realised the offending arm was a sleeve from the hussar's pelisse.

print_settings.Notes:: Print the train at no more than 30% speed.

description.text:
My 7-year-old son just started reading his first chapter book, so he wanted a nice new bookmark. I told him to design something and I would print one out for him (his drawing can be seen in the images above). I've tried to thicken the walls as much as I could without badly distorting the image, but it is still quite thin, so this needs to be printed slowly. I printed the flat bookmark part at normal speed and then printed the train itself at 30%. It worked pretty well for the most part, but my printer had a little trouble with the engineer, so bumping it down a little more might be ideal. At my son's request, the very top has a small ring that can be used to attach a ribbon or key ring.

I can't imagine there would be much interest in this because there are plenty of higher-quality options available, but I'm a proud father, so here we are.

author: michalhoudek

description.text:
This an M16 mine, a bounding anti-personel mine based on the German WW2 S-mine.
Many of these were used in Vietnam, with or without some sort of tripwire. Sometimes another device was planted underneath this one. When you tried to disarm the M16 mine the one underneath would go of.

Size 1:1

The body is 1 part, de fuze is 2-part, you need to glue them together.
I made the fuse with a screwable thread.
I made holes for the pins, I used paperclips on mine. The wires are to thin to print nicely.

The mine in the picture is not mine (mine got it? ;))
It's a practice model.

UPDATE: uploaded the complete mine with fuse inserted.

entretoise de securite pour pistolet a air comprimé
keychain wrench for m8 bolts

Dual drive direct extruder - Very grippy, designed to work with flexible filaments.
Normally you will have bearing pushing against the gear to drive filament, I replaced bearing with another gear. This way I eliminated smooth bearing surface and achieved superior grip, your filament will more likely break than slide.

At this moment I'm testing my first prototype. It prints flexible TPU filament successfully, and retraction works fine too.

One thing to consider when printing flexible filaments, your flow rate must be setup properly, other wise filament will kink, I left too much space between gears and heatsink. It still works fine as long as u have correct settings.
I'm working on this issue, along with other improvements on version 2.

Parts list:

  • 11x 625-2RS Bearings
  • 6x Gt2 16T pulleys
  • 1x GT2 60T pulley
  • 3x 102-GT2 looped belt
  • Nema pancake motor
  • 5mm rods, 5mm washers
  • 2x 32P pitch 5mm shaft 21T Pinion Gear
  • 2x Drive gear - 1x MK8 Extruder Drive Gear Hobbed , 1x 40 Teeth 5mm Bore Mk7/8 Drive Gear normal
  • J-head hotend
